summary: Paul Merson reignited his criticism of Andros Townsend after the latter was substituted in late during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously questioned Townsend’s place in the England squad, which led to tension between the two. However, Townsend responded by scoring for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit he was wrong. Despite this, Merson took another jab at Townsend after the Burnley match, suggesting ongoing tension.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer goes through, Muto will join Chelsea’s Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane stated the bid is unrelated to Chelsea’s £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 11 international caps for Japan and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo. He is honored by Chelsea's offer but has not yet decided whether to accept it.

A large study found that babies given antibiotics within their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, based on over 12,000 Finnish children, showed a higher risk of obesity — especially in boys — linked to early or repeated antibiotic use. Though it doesn’t prove causation, the study suggests antibiotics may affect gut bacteria, altering metabolism and appetite. Authors warn that this may contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic and highlight the importance of careful antibiotic use in infants. The findings add to concerns about over-prescription and antibiotic resistance.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a young Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell in front of hundreds of tourists, dropping his rifle and hitting his bearskin hat on the sentry box. The moment, which was filmed by tourist David Meadwell, showed the guard quickly scrambling to his feet, visibly embarrassed. The incident is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. Despite the fall, his fellow guards continued as normal. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally drew over 100 million viewers, for broadcast in 2016 on A&E, Lifetime, and History. The new version will be more contemporary, draw further from Alex Haley's novel, and consult African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The project aims to introduce the story to a new generation amid modern racial issues, with the goal of continuing to share Kunta Kinte's enduring legacy.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims he was sexually assaulted by palace aides at Clarence House in 1978 on his first day of work. He alleges he was pinned to a chair and groped by staff, then threatened when he tried to report the incident. His initial complaints were ignored, but after renewed enquiries into historic abuse cases, police are now investigating. The Palace has since agreed to cooperate fully with the investigation. A retired aide denies involvement.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a YouTube rap video set to the theme of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which includes Melissa rapping about discovering the pregnancy and ends with a sonogram reveal, has been viewed over 1.7 million times. It was created to share the news with distant loved ones and became more popular than the couple expected. Jesse, a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, had previously learned about the pregnancy through a tag on their dog. The couple is considering making another video after learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, featuring over 150 items from the movie. The faded ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in key scenes and belonged to James Tumblin's extensive memorabilia collection, which he began in the 1960s. Other highlighted auction items included a hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year, and Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, was the first African-American to win an Oscar.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the railing while holding another child. He was rescued by his parents before emergency responders arrived and suffered only minor injuries. The cheetahs did not approach the boy. Eyewitnesses reported the child was dangled over the railing, prompting the zoo to plan child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was subsequently closed.

A non-functioning speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, previously used to enforce a 30mph limit, has mysteriously been turned to point directly at a house. The camera, along with around 300 others, was deactivated in 2013 due to outdated technology. Mobile units and patrol officers now handle speed enforcement. Birmingham City Council is aware of the camera's repositioning and may remove it, confirming it is not part of plans for a new digital technology pilot. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, expressed his readiness and pride in representing his country. The JAAA is pleased with his participation, and the full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their support for Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball El Clasico with Neymar’s sister, Rafaella, where Barcelona narrowly beat Real Madrid 85-80. Despite the win, Real Madrid still leads the division on points difference. Neymar had recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium amid a physical match. Before the international break, Barcelona won their football El Clasico, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga, and they return to league action against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble.

Italy is facing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe via the Mediterranean. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued. A ship possibly carrying 550 migrants reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, with 145 rescued and 400 feared missing, though the Italian coast guard has found no evidence of the incident. The International Organization for Migration reports over 10,000 arrivals in Italy in early 2015 and at least 480 migrant deaths due to poor conditions and overcrowded boats. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, often transiting through Libya.

Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool after leaving Barcelona, though boss Arsene Wenger is unsure why. Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision, noting the Chilean has quickly adapted to English football, scoring 19 goals this season. While Liverpool had interest in Sanchez, potentially tied to the Suarez transfer, Wenger emphasizes Sanchez’s qualities and impact. Wenger also praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers' ability to adapt after losing Suarez and dealing with injuries, and dismissed speculation linking Arsenal with Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, is 52.491km. Wiggins, who ended his Team Sky career at the recent Paris-Roubaix race, is preparing for this challenge as he returns to track cycling, aiming for an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games. Tickets for the event go on sale April 19 via Sky Tickets, with the attempt to be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, admitted her tough win over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup was an 'eye-opener' as she adjusts to the claycourt season. Though she maintained an 8-0 record over Errani with a 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 win, the U.S. ultimately lost 3-2 to Italy after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated in the doubles match. Williams acknowledged she is not yet fully prepared for clay courts. The U.S. was relegated to World Group II, and captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for continued effort to return to the top level.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them before moving to Porto in 2009. Despite his struggles during a loan spell at Manchester United, where he scored only four Premier League goals, River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed hope of Falcao’s return, saying "the doors are open." Falcao, currently still under contract with Monaco, has recently equaled Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. He originally joined River Plate in 2001 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for their first team.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from The X Factor 2012, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The partnership, arranged by the MILES agency, features a TV ad using her single "Mirror Man" and showcases various hairstyles against a city backdrop. Henderson expressed excitement, noting she regularly uses Batiste products. Crown Talent & Media Group CEO Mark Hargreaves highlighted the natural synergy between the artist and the popular dry shampoo brand.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after a police chase; Siler was reportedly armed and wanted on a felony warrant. The shooting is under investigation, and Torres is on leave. A billboard featuring Torres and thanking the community for support, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, has sparked outrage from Siler’s family and friends, who find it disrespectful. The police association claims no offense was intended. Torres had also shot another man, Terry Knight, ten days earlier; that shooting was later deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants in Negur, near the Pakistan border. Iranian forces killed three militants, who had reportedly crossed from Pakistan. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility. Iran requested Pakistan help capture the remaining attackers. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni group from Balochistan, has a history of targeting Iran. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and pledged to investigate and cooperate with Iran.

In response to lawmaker and former wrestler Antonio Inoki's question, Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered any extraterrestrial UFOs. Nakatani explained that while jets are scrambled to investigate potential airspace violations, no sightings have been confirmed as alien in origin. Inoki, known for his wrestling career and political activism, claimed to have seen a UFO and has a history of unorthodox diplomacy efforts. This is not the first time Japanese politicians have raised questions about extraterrestrial threats.

A 35-year-old man, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts after a toilet he was standing on collapsed at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. He squatted on the toilet rim to avoid touching the seat, fearing it was unclean, but the porcelain toilet broke, causing serious injuries. Initially, he admitted this to friends but later told police he was sitting when it broke, possibly to avoid liability. Authorities treated it as an accident and reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over four years and secretly filming her and others in a bathroom using a hidden camera. The abuse began when the victim was nine and continued until she was 13. The investigation started after the now 15-year-old girl found the camera in her home. Prosecutors discovered 41 videos, many showing victims, including minors, in the shower. Rebbie admitted to making the recordings, primarily targeting the 15-year-old. He faces multiple charges and is held on $500,000 bail, with a hearing set for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s latest photo series, featured in his book *Daughter and Salaryman*, depicts fathers in suits leaping energetically next to their casually dressed, po-faced daughters. The aim is to show fathers expressing a fun, heroic side, contrasting with their usual serious demeanor. Set against various Japanese landmarks, the quirky portraits have gained online attention for their unusual and humorous nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the door for Kevin Pietersen, previously dropped in 2014, to potentially return to the England team. As the county championship season begins, Pietersen appeared thoughtful yet cheerful during Surrey’s team photo at the KIA Oval. He aims to impress and regain his Test spot, with Surrey starting their campaign on April 19 and playing Oxford MCCU in a warm-up match.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, struggling in relegation, have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international, was initially fired, then reinstated by owner Angelo Massone, but dismissed again after the defeat. He was Ceahlaul's third coach this season, having replaced Florin Marin in January, and will now be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul sit 16th in the standings, six points from safety.

Radamel Falcao, unhappy during his time at Monaco, moved to Manchester United on a season-long loan but struggled to perform following a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals. His former teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets leaving Monaco, where he would have played more and participated in the Champions League, despite not feeling well there. Manchester United are unlikely to make his £46 million transfer permanent.

A tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a dairy in east Christchurch, New Zealand, stealing the till and about $1,500. The robbery occurred around 12:30pm on Saturday, and no weapons were used. Police are seeking public help to identify the masked suspect, who remains at large.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for alleged inappropriate relationships with two 15-year-old students. Initially arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year, she was later arrested again following claims from a second student that they had sex in her car on two nights in January. Both arrests stemmed from police investigations prompted by reports within the school. Granado has been placed on administrative leave and released on bail.

A video showing a crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, swimming through a marina with a dead dog in its jaws has gone viral, gaining over 500,000 views. The dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, was attacked after approaching the water out of curiosity. Tourist Tim Weston witnessed and photographed the scene, describing the crocodile holding the dog for hours. The incident, which occurred near a crocodile sanctuary, sparked horrified reactions online. Crocodiles are common in the area due to nearby mangroves and increasing urbanization, often bringing them into closer contact with humans.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which left them just two points above the drop zone. Initially aiming for 10 wins to survive, Hull has managed only six, with Bruce now hoping eight or nine might suffice. He attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players but believes they can still stay up with six games remaining, including tough matches against top teams. Meanwhile, Southampton moved to fifth place, though manager Ronald Koeman faced issues with Sadio Mane challenging penalty-taking protocol.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, was banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing students to alter their SATs exam answers and making changes himself after the exam had ended. This misconduct led to the annulment of all the school's SATs results for 2014 following an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick admitted to the actions, claiming he only asked pupils to make answers more legible, but a conduct panel found this unacceptable. Though he showed remorse, his actions were deemed deliberate, resulting in a prohibition order with a 28-day window to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper who joined Manchester United in 2010, has struggled for playing time, making only 19 league appearances over five seasons and now ranks third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Off the pitch, however, he is enjoying personal success, having married Swedish-Albanian model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach ceremony in Mauritius. The couple, who have been together since 2012 and have a son, frequently share moments from their life on Instagram. Lindegaard was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland, but no deal was reached.

Thirteen large blue letters that once sat atop Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby’s auction, despite being valued between $300,000 and $600,000. Owned by Yankee legend Reggie Jackson since 2008, the letters attracted no real bids, with only a Sotheby’s employee placing a $260,000 bid to spark interest. Installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008, the letters were purchased by Jackson "on a lark." In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, sold for $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers, Liverpool’s manager, addressed incidents involving Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe using nitrous oxide and shisha pipes, reminding them of their professional responsibilities. He chose not to discipline them but emphasized learning from the experience. Sterling will lead the team in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa due to Daniel Sturridge's injury, with Steven Gerrard available after suspension. Rodgers remains focused on reaching his first FA Cup final with Liverpool, citing past near-misses as motivation for success.

Mesut Ozil, after returning to London from international duty where he helped Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier, shared a photo relaxing at home with his dog. He is preparing for Arsenal’s upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool, having missed the previous game due to illness. Despite reports of him being at a nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed the claims. Since returning from injury, Ozil has been in strong form for Arsenal with four assists and three goals, and he says he has now fully adjusted to the demands of English football.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated the club is very happy with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him. Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer, is close to winning the La Liga title and has impressed during his tenure. Despite rumors of a summer replacement, Bartomeu praised Enrique’s work and focus. Barcelona remains in contention for three trophies this season, and recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay until 2020 with improved terms worth around £100,000 a week. The 24-year-old midfielder becomes the third key player under manager Brendan Rodgers to sign a new deal, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, signed from Sunderland in 2011, has been in excellent form, contributing 13 assists and 7 goals this season, and is a candidate to become club captain when Steven Gerrard departs. Contract talks with Raheem Sterling are ongoing, with discussions expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite interest from Atletico Madrid in re-signing him. Although he has struggled for a regular place, he remains committed to the club. After playing for Brazil in international friendlies, he now focuses on helping Chelsea in the Premier League title race, following manager Jose Mourinho's push for full concentration during the season's final games.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after being initially suspended for accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27. The disciplinary panel had originally ruled his knee-to-head collision as reckless, despite no intent, leading to his red card and suspension. However, following widespread outcry and new evidence, the appeal panel concluded no foul play had occurred. Hughes is now cleared to play, though he is not expected to return until April 26. Meanwhile, North, who was concussed for the third time in two months, has been advised to rest for at least a month.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, caused by farmers burning grass and intensified by strong winds, destroyed several villages. The resulting smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest due to atmospheric winds. This smoke caused intense red and orange sunsets in regions like Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia. The vivid colors occur because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, especially during sunrise and sunset. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the reddish sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway, but it was recovered after a man named Mick Sexton recognized the car and alerted police. The vehicle was returned with new red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping" her ride. Despite the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, which she is addressing with professional cleaning, she is showing gratitude by naming a new smoothie at her restaurant after Sexton.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League, due to incentivised contracts designed to comply with financial fair play rules. After a defeat to Manchester United, City's top-four hopes are uncertain, with Liverpool close behind. The squad could lose a total of £12 million in bonuses, and failure to qualify may hinder their ability to attract top players like Paul Pogba. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team’s season has collapsed following multiple defeats and early exits from competitions.

Manchester United's Under-18 team defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal through a free-kick. The match featured a strong local presence, with 13 English players, including 10 Mancunians, and was played in front of around 1,000 fans. United's coach Paul McGuinness aimed to simulate a senior-level experience, employing a similar formation. Despite chances for both sides, United secured the win and remain two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand. The match highlighted promising homegrown talent on both teams.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th international cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who reached his own milestone with his 50th cap, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and professionalism, calling him an inspiration. Hart, ten years younger than Buffon, hopes to continue improving and increasing his number of caps for both club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver orders in 67 cities. This marks a shift from its previous stance of declining third-party delivery services. Deliveries will include a 9% service charge, and Postmates fees start at $5 based on distance and demand. The move follows similar plans by other major food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King. Additionally, Chipotle has recently seen visits from presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, highlighting its popularity.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are pleading for the death penalty to be removed for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard describe their family's suffering and argue that a life sentence without parole and no rights to appeal would spare them and their surviving children further prolonged trauma. They believe ending the pursuit of the death penalty would help bring closure and promote healing.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747-8, typically used to carry up to 600 passengers, into a £400 million luxury private jet over a three-year customization period. Designed to host the owner and several dozen guests, the jet features lavish accommodations including a master bedroom, multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds. The interior resembles a high-end hotel, with custom features like a state room, office space, and television lounge, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station (ISS). While the Dragon is en route to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, the attempt to land the rocket’s first stage on a floating barge failed, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. This was SpaceX’s second attempt at a barge landing, part of efforts to develop reusable rockets to reduce spaceflight costs. The Dragon will remain at the ISS for about five weeks before returning to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This marks SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission and the second attempt for this specific launch following a weather delay.

Priscilla Presley will act as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel in the Westgate Hotel, Las Vegas, on April 23. The wedding is part of a contest organized with NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win an "ultimate wedding," including a free reception, a hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized the event is to be taken seriously, with no impersonators allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples entered the contest by submitting videos or photos explaining why they deserved to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, which marked the 47th game of the season for both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet. The win, following disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal, reduced the gap to City to four points. Goals came from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, with Allen acknowledging a possible missed penalty for Newcastle. Despite challenges, Liverpool remains focused on winning and maintaining pressure in the race for the Champions League.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League spots. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis preserved the lead with key saves. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio and extended Napoli’s winless run to five games. Security was heightened due to past fan violence, but no incidents occurred. Roma played without injured stars Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli’s Insigne returned from injury late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers' lackluster season continued with a dull 0-0 draw against Fleetwood Town, leaving both fans and the club’s media team uninspired. The match offered little excitement, resulting in a 27-second highlights video on the team's YouTube channel, featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has developed a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986. Unlike most marine pets, this fish enjoys physical interaction; Giroux regularly massages it by hand, and the fish responds by swimming back to him and staying still for strokes. After removing two bullying tankmates, Giroux began hand-feeding the fish frozen blood worms, which led it to become more sociable. The fish now expects daily play and becomes frustrated without it. Giroux documents this relationship in videos shared on his YouTube channel.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, has returned to the England cricket team after a tumultuous year marked by injury and disciplinary issues. His passion and aggression, exemplified by past clashes and on-field intensity, are seen as assets if properly managed. England coach Peter Moores has played a key role in guiding Stokes to channel his emotions constructively. While concerns remain about controlling his temper and avoiding being pigeonholed, England values his potential to contribute significantly with both bat and ball and aims to give him consistent opportunities to develop.

Wales’ crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the 33,000-capacity Cardiff City Stadium has sold out. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points, though Belgium holds first place on goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has boosted hopes of qualifying for their first major tournament since 1958. Despite high demand, the match will remain at Cardiff City Stadium due to UEFA venue rules, and the Wales squad favors playing there over the larger Millennium Stadium.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria next month. The team, defending champions after beating Holland last year, qualified with a perfect record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Ireland. They will face Italy first on May 7. The 18-player squad features youth talents from top Premier League clubs, including debut call-up Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal) and returning Liverpool duo Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously turned down Barcelona to focus on his education. City have held talks with Anderlecht to agree on a compensation deal as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to invest in future prospects.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, was found dead from head and neck injuries in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but later released on bail. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her before her death. Santillan had recently come to London from Miami and had worked in London, Paris, and Miami as an escort. The investigation is ongoing.

Dawn, a woman who suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* to confront her housemate and longtime friend, Jamie, a convicted burglar, for stealing £207 she had saved for her baby's gravestone. A lie detector test confirmed Jamie had taken the money, leading Dawn to break down in tears. Jamie had also confessed in a Facebook message but blamed his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal, as the money was intended to honor her buried child, Daniel James.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, the ill, and elderly, after capturing them during its takeover of northern Iraq in summer 2014. The reason for the release is unclear but may have involved Arab tribal leaders. The released individuals were received by Kurdish Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. The Yazidi minority, of Kurdish descent and followers of a pre-Islamic religion, has faced long-term persecution and suffered atrocities including mass killings and enslavement by ISIS. A humanitarian crisis followed ISIS’ capture of Sinjar, prompting international aid and U.S.-led airstrikes.

Harry Kane has had a remarkable season, breaking into Tottenham's first team and England's national squad, and is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animated video by Copa90 showcases his standout goals and celebrations, including moments against Chelsea, Arsenal, and Newcastle, as well as his debut England goal. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", highlights his achievements ahead of the upcoming awards ceremony.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers continuing as Liverpool manager despite a third trophy-less season and missing out on the top four. He believes Rodgers and his staff can improve next season with better signings. Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation, which supports schools in deprived areas of Merseyside. He emphasizes giving back to his hometown of Bootle and inspiring local youth.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security staff deemed it a risk. Despite being a brightly colored toy, it was flagged during X-ray screening, leading to a pat-down and removal of the toy. James’s father criticized the action as over-zealous. Though the airport apologized and offered to mail the toy home, they defended their decision, citing regulations that ban items resembling prohibited weapons. The family later replaced the £6 toy after their holiday.

A man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a detailed online advertisement seeking a girlfriend or wife. In his ad on Gumtree, he listed specific requirements for a partner—such as being fit, attractive, non-smoking, good with household tasks, and both adventurous and feminine. Rich described himself as a successful, athletic, tattooed 31-year-old with properties and a love for the outdoors. He offered perks like accommodation, a company car, and other benefits, emphasizing that all reasonable offers would be considered. Attempts to contact him were unsuccessful.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is proposing changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from 8 to 12 and to redefine "home-grown" as players trained in England for three years before age 18. Despite opposition from the Premier League, five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—support Dyke's proposals. They warn that without action, England risks falling further behind in international football due to a shrinking pool of top-level English talent. The managers highlight the emergence of promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, but argue these talents need more opportunities to develop.

In the latest episode of *Poldark*, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, quickly progresses from barely showing to giving birth to a baby daughter, a timeline that fans noted as unrealistic. Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, is shown to be affectionately involved despite having married Demelza out of duty. Viewers have commented on the show’s rapid pregnancy timelines, comparing it to a previous storyline involving the character Elizabeth.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused on their own performance and not be distracted by relegation rivals, despite recent back-to-back wins improving their survival hopes. After a dramatic 3-2 victory over West Brom, with Jamie Vardy scoring a late winner, Leicester remains bottom but just three points from safety. Pearson emphasized that their future is in their own hands and warned against over-optimism as the team continues their fight to avoid relegation.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set a new record for the longest mammal migration by swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. Tracked by Oregon State University scientists, her journey surpassed the previous record of 10,190 miles by a humpback whale. Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern, not western, gray whale—a finding that could impact estimates of the already endangered western gray whale population.

Overnight, a 1,000–1,640ft long and 100ft wide section of seabed unexpectedly rose up to 50ft above sea level along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Japan’s Hokkaido Island. Geologists attribute the emergence to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which shifted land and pushed the seabed upward. Residents were surprised, reporting no tremors or sounds. Authorities confirmed it was unrelated to recent seismic activity and do not expect further movement. Marine organisms remain visible on the new landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors about leaving Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates despite a recent conflict with coach Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a match. He stated a desire to sign a new contract, but his future may be uncertain due to PSG’s interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves.

Carlos Tevez wants to leave Juventus before his contract ends in 2016 to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Boca's president confirmed they are close to finalizing the deal but stressed that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite being Juventus' top scorer and nearing a second Serie A title, the club is preparing for his departure. Tevez has long expressed a desire to finish his career at Boca, where he began his professional journey. His potential move won't affect his standing with Argentina's national team.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena, overturning a 3-1 first-leg deficit to reach the Champions League semi-finals. Goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. During the match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore his trousers in the excitement, revealing his underwear and joking afterward about needing a new pair.

A three-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale involved ten people, including four children. Multiple individuals sustained injuries, with four, including a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy, airlifted to Brisbane hospitals. Six others, including an infant, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. Emergency crews had to free one trapped person using hydraulic tools. The highway was closed with diversions due to the incident.

Arsenal will face league leaders Chelsea this Sunday in a crucial Premier League match. Arsenal's Mesut Ozil showcased his excitement by sharing his new Apple Watch on Instagram, comparing it to a gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is set to start the match. Arsenal are 10 points behind Chelsea with six games left, and their squad is strengthened by Jack Wilshere’s return from injury. Club legend Ray Parlour supports Wilshere’s potential but questions his ability to remain injury-free for a full season.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from Manchester United and City this season. He is generally seen as one of the Premier League's top referees. United, currently on a five-game winning streak, sit one point above City, who have struggled recently. The derby could influence who finishes second behind Chelsea. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of expecting embattled MP Billy Gordon, who recently left the Labor Party over domestic violence allegations and a concealed criminal history, to resign, describing the government’s attitude as seeing Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string." Katter's comments, made in defense of Gordon remaining in parliament as an independent, sparked social media criticism for racial insensitivity. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, defended his remarks by citing his own experiences with racism and claiming he intended to highlight racial overtones in the government's response.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, uses dance videos to challenge stereotypes about disabilities and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and low expectations, she emphasizes her similarities to others and aims to promote better representation of people with disabilities in media. Dayna has created multiple videos, including one set to Taylor Swift’s "Shake It Off," and has started motivational speaking at local schools to spread her positive message.

Orlando City are interested in signing Manchester United’s Javier Hernandez, who has struggled on loan at Real Madrid. The Florida-based MLS club, backed by a strong Latin-American fanbase and captained by Kaka, sees Hernandez as a major commercial and fan draw. However, eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan—are also interested, with United willing to sell for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who is also being pursued by top European clubs like PSG, Juventus, PSV, and Feyenoord.

Early Saturday morning at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles, at least three suspects attempted to carjack a man and then set his car on fire by dousing it with gasoline. The incident occurred around 12:15am and followed an argument between the driver and suspects. Despite two passengers being inside the vehicle, no one was injured, though the car was severely damaged. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects have not been apprehended. Surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to unethical practices, including accepting sex as payment, performing exorcisms on patients, and advising them to stop taking prescribed medication. He agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the issues leading to the revocation no longer exist before practicing again. Despite these actions, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 jet over international airspace in the Baltic Sea, near Poland. The U.S. deemed the Russian pilot's maneuvers unsafe and unprofessional, while Russia claimed the U.S. plane was approaching its border with its transponder off—a claim the U.S. denies. The U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint. Similar incidents have occurred before, including a dangerous encounter over the Sea of Okhotsk a year earlier, as U.S. and Russian aircraft frequently cross paths in areas near Europe and the Pacific.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen from his vehicle overnight on March 27 in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, shortly before President Obama’s visit to Utah. The rifle was locked in a hard case and secured to a truck safe, but the thief broke a car window and used a rope and vehicle momentum to forcibly remove it. Additional items including bags and clothing were also taken, though some were later recovered nearby. The rifle remains missing, and the theft may not have specifically targeted the agent. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and the Secret Service was notified before the President’s visit.

In July 2012, 71-year-old Luigi Costa was accused of brutally murdering his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol-induced confusion at the time, citing erratic behavior and evidence from the crime scene. Costa's mental state is central to the case, as the jury may deliver a not guilty verdict if it is proven he was not mentally sound during the attack.

In Everton’s 1-0 win over Burnley, Ross Barkley missed an early penalty despite regular taker Leighton Baines being on the pitch. This echoed a previous incident involving Kevin Mirallas. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley’s decision, stating he was entitled to take the penalty and praising his responsibility. The miss did not affect the outcome as Kevin Mirallas later scored the winning goal.

Two passengers were found dead in their cabin aboard the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The ship, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise from Tampa, had docked in San Juan when cleaning staff discovered the bodies. Authorities, including the FBI, are investigating the incident.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, led Curacao to the second round of 2018 World Cup CONCACAF qualifying. Curacao advanced with a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat, including a late goal by Charlton Vicento. Kluivert, who has Curacaoan heritage, will next face Cuba with his team on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer with major titles from Inter Milan and Real Madrid, considers helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift with eight games left, he remains optimistic about survival, praising his teammates and expressing satisfaction with his time at the club. Signed on a one-year deal, Cambiasso has become a key player and is open to extending his stay.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma risks being banned from seeing her young children by her mother, Debbie, who has raised them since infancy due to Gemma's irresponsible behavior. Debbie cites Gemma's ongoing partying, substance abuse, suspected theft, and neglect as reasons for her decision. Despite Gemma denying some allegations, she admits to stealing from her mother. Debbie, who appeared with Gemma on The Jeremy Kyle Show, says she is forced to act to protect her grandchildren, whom she has raised and who now call her "mum."

Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead over Manchester United following a build-up that involved a controversial challenge by John Terry on Radamel Falcao. The Sky Sports pundits—Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp—unanimously agreed that Terry's strong tackle from behind was a foul and that play should have been stopped before the goal.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway after a rear tire blew out, but all on board — including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver — were safely evacuated. Bystander Michael Barnett captured video of the incident, and Scott later shared that everything in the back lounge was destroyed except her Bible. Other band members were not on the bus. The group is scheduled to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards in Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a space laser system to convert sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors. The laser-generated energy would be beamed to Earth to enhance solar panels, potentially benefiting regions like Scotland and disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland succeeded, with further testing planned in Portugal. The lasers are not powerful enough for weaponization, though Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns over satellite control. Separately, Tokyo researchers proposed a weaker laser system for the ISS to eliminate space debris.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a known obsession with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire where he was held under a hospital order for sexually touching a three-year-old girl. Munden, who has learning difficulties and autism, was last seen leaving the hospital and may have altered his appearance by shaving his beard. He has a history of non-contact and contact sexual offences involving children, including possession of indecent images. Police have launched a manhunt and are urgently appealing for information on his whereabouts.

A judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after being sued by Shelly Sterling, wife of former NBA team owner Donald Sterling. The lawsuit accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and receiving luxury items funded by the Sterlings' shared wealth. The court ruling is seen as a victory for Shelly Sterling and sets a legal precedent. Donald Sterling previously lost his NBA team after a racist audio recording involving Stiviano surfaced, leading to his lifetime ban and fine by the NBA.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal's recent transfer activity and urged the club to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, centre-back, defensive midfielder, and top striker—to boost their chances of winning the Premier League. Speaking after Arsenal's draw with Chelsea, he questioned whether Olivier Giroud is capable of leading the team to a league title, despite Giroud scoring 14 goals. Henry emphasized the need for high-calibre signings similar to those made by Chelsea, such as Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa, to create a competitive squad.

Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman and Bega Cheese executive, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims testified in Sydney's District Court about the lasting emotional trauma she has suffered, including fear of future relationships, depression, and attempted suicide. She revealed she kept the abuse secret for years, only speaking out after learning Van Ryn had been caught. The court hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a first-team return after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal’s Under-21s and reports feeling increasingly better, indicating he is now over his injury.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant and university graduate, died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing a taxi to avoid paying the fare following a night out. He and two friends exited the cab under the pretense of using an ATM, then ran off in different directions. Disoriented in the dark, Phillips leapt over a fence and unknowingly fell off a cliff. His body was found the next morning. The coroner ruled his death accidental, noting he likely had no idea of the danger due to poor visibility.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delays received little to no compensation, despite HM Passport Office making a £42.3 million profit during the crisis and awarding up to £3,500 in bonuses to managers. Though over half a million passports were delayed, with many people paying extra for fast-tracked services or missing trips, only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, averaging £92.68. Ministers refused widespread reimbursements, rejecting calls from the Home Affairs Committee. Investigation revealed that nearly no affected travelers recovered any costs, as database issues also obscured the number of rejected claims.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. Untouched for over 80 years, the three-bedroom semi-detached house retains original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, wood-panelled hallway, vintage cupboards, and a mint green and black bathroom. It also contains retro items like tins of dried milk and mustard. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, auctioneers note renovation costs may deter developers. The property will be auctioned on April 30.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion, leading the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and later lived in Texas and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 through the Lincoln Tunnel to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and formed the band Blur, whose first album *Leisure* was released in 1991. Blur gained influence from various music genres and achieved global success with their self-titled album in 2001. Albarn released his debut solo album *Everyday Robots* on 28 April 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with artists like Brian Eno and Natasha Khan.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia and hosts many of the country’s key national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 debut EP, *Broken*.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film *Shooter* features Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series adaptation stars Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an expert marksman drawn out of exile to stop a presidential assassination plot.
*House (also called House, M.D.)* is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of nine people, including actress Sharon Tate, committed by his followers under his orders. Following his charges, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career on television in 1974 and had his film debut in *Taps* (1981). Gaining recognition through roles in the 1980s and early 1990s, he became a leading actor with *Dead Man Walking* (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination. Penn later won Oscars for *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008), with additional nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (1908–2001) was an Australian cricketer, widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has held top executive roles at major music labels, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, Arista Records, and Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of Prophets of Rage. (Note: The passage also mentions a different band named Rage, a German heavy metal band formed in 1984, unrelated to Wilk.)

*The Millers* was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of the second season had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was a Democratic politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She gained national attention as Texas state treasurer and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and sharp wit. She lost her re-election bid in 1994 to George W. Bush. The passage also mentions a different person, Ann Richards (1935–1982), an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled *A Reminder* in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, appeared in the film and wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the independence movements that resulted in the creation of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign nations free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under mysterious conditions.

Colin Kaepernick began as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter in 2012 after Alex Smith's concussion. He led the team to the Super Bowl that season, where they lost to the Ravens, and in 2013, helped them reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication using openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. It differs from personal selling by not targeting individuals directly and is delivered through traditional media (e.g., newspapers, TV) or new media (e.g., websites, text messages).
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, later adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at age 17 or 18 and stayed until about 347 BC. After Plato’s death, he left Athens and began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is a former American arms dealer who later became a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning five NBA championships and a Finals MVP as a rookie. After initial success in high school and college, he was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft. He briefly returned to play in 1996 before retiring for the third time. Beyond basketball, he became a successful businessman and was named one of America's most influential Black businessmen by Ebony in 2009.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and touring with major rock acts. The band has released three albums: *Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006), and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012).

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland in 1603, ruling both realms in a personal union. While successful in Scotland, he faced major challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and repeated conflicts with Parliament. He supported the idea of a unified parliament for England and Scotland.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, a British actor and voice-over artist known for his Geordie accent, has narrated the UK version of Big Brother since 2000 and is recognized as one of Britain’s most familiar voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering four German states and two countries—Poland and the Czech Republic. It ranks tenth in area and sixth in population among Germany’s sixteen states. With over a thousand years of history, Saxony is also notable for being one of Germany's northernmost wine regions, located in former East Germany alongside the Saale-Unstrut region.
The passage mentions that East End Park was a former major league baseball park in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, and that "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown launched her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

*Mohra* is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of the year and received nine Filmfare nominations. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death. The film is also noted for its popular soundtrack.

The passage provides information about two works titled "Hourglass": one is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and the other is the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, known for writing the 1987 action film *Lethal Weapon* and making his directorial debut with *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang* in 2005.
*A View to a Kill* (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, located in western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya, and earlier as West Irian or Irian Barat, encompassing all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with her debut album *On the 6*. In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album (*J.Lo*) and film (*The Wedding Planner*) in the same week. Her relationship with Ben Affleck inspired her 2002 album *This Is Me... Then*, though their film *Gigli* (2003) failed. She later married Marc Anthony and found box office success with *Shall We Dance?*. After giving birth to twins in 2008 and a quieter period, she returned to prominence in 2011 as an *American Idol* judge and released her biggest hit, "On the Floor."

A working animal is a typically domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks such as guiding, assisting, providing tractive force, milking, or herding. While usually trusted and mild-tempered, wild animals are occasionally trained for work, mainly for novelty or entertainment.

The passage describes "Billboard Dad" as a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. It also explains that Billboard magazine publishes key music charts, including the Top Latin Albums chart for Spanish-language albums and the Regional Mexican Albums chart for genre-specific music in the U.S.

"Vedam" (English: Chant) is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring a cast that includes Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

*Men in Black II* (stylized as *MIIB*) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring a cast that includes Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from the 1605 novel *Don Quixote* by Miguel de Cervantes. He serves as Don Quixote's squire and is known for his humorous and witty remarks, called "sanchismos," which mix irony, Spanish proverbs, and earthy humor.
*The Adventures of Pluto Nash* is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film directed by Ron Underwood and starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role.
The world premiere of *Hedda Gabler* took place on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen present.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, commonly known as Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, founded in 1897 by young local students including Eugenio and Enrico Canfari. It is the second oldest still-active football club in Italy after Genoa, has worn a black and white striped kit since 1903, and currently plays at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in films and TV series during the late 1990s and early 2000s, including *Kate & Leopold* (2001), *Far from Heaven* (2002), and *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress. Known as "The Queen of Porn," she began her career in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a National Basketball Association (NBA) team that competes in the Western Conference's Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, originally by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It transitioned from closed-circuit to pay-per-view broadcasts. The event was part of a tradition by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) to host major wrestling shows on holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, mainly at Greensboro Coliseum. Notable editions include Starrcade 1985 (third annual), Starrcade 1987 (fifth annual), and Starrcade 1997 (fifteenth annual).
Jack Falahee, born February 20, 1989, is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on ABC's "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's "Mercy Street."

"Don't Say No" is the debut mini album by Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress who debuted with Girls' Generation in 2007. She is the third member of the group to launch a solo career, releasing her first solo work on January 17, 2017. In addition to her music career, she has acted in various musicals including "Moon Embracing the Sun," "Gone with the Wind," and "Mamma Mia."

The Apple II, introduced in 1977, is an 8-bit home computer and one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputers. It was primarily designed by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs overseeing the case design and Rod Holt developing the power supply. The Apple II series was manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Wozniak, known as "Woz," is a co-founder of Apple and an influential figure in technology.

A&E is an American cable and satellite TV channel and the flagship of A&E Networks, a joint venture equally owned by Hearst Corporation and Disney–ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid has held top executive roles in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, Arista Records, and Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.
The title "Veeram" refers to two Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

The passage describes two films titled *Home for the Holidays*. The first is a 1972 American made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field and others; it premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. The second is a 1995 film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., and a large ensemble cast.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
"The Sex Factor" is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster, featuring eight men and eight women competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label and a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a state in northeastern India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character in J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by Jack Binder, and released by Columbia Pictures on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

In 2016, Sheryl Lee appeared in *Café Society* and completed the *Twin Peaks* revival, reprising her role as Laura Palmer. That same year, Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in *Wicked* on Broadway.
Matteo Renzi is an Italian politician who served as Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado is a film featuring a cast that includes Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love" is a song by American singer Selena Gomez from her 2015 album *Revival*, which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. The song, along with "Good for You" and "Hands to Myself," topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the U.S.
"Weekly Idol" is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the UK and US, with bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon continuing its development in the late 1970s as part of the new wave of British heavy metal.

Rage Against the Machine broke up after de la Rocha left due to internal tensions. He began a solo career, while the other members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before splitting in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella. Their fourth studio album, *Renegades*, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a free-float market-weighted index comprising 30 well-established companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of the companies included in the SENSEX and is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has a population of approximately 92.7 million, making it the 14th most populous country globally and ninth in Asia. It shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, and has maritime boundaries with Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced rapid economic growth and had the highest Global Growth Generators Index in 2011 among 11 major economies. It is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states that officially practice communism.
*Dreamer* is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two violent acts against British rule and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death, ruling both Scotland and England in a personal union. Despite the separate parliaments, laws, and judiciaries of the two kingdoms, James advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland and faced many challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original cast member of Shortland Street and is known for roles in Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, and Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in Wentworth, which she starred in for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in several films including *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups*, and *Grown Ups 2*. *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser* is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

"Artpop" received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales. It was Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the US and sold 2.3 million copies worldwide in 2013, making it the ninth best-selling album of that year.
In 2006, the Red Hot Chili Peppers released *Stadium Arcadium*, their fifth and final album with guitarist John Frusciante, who left the band in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism; she remains a controversial yet influential figure in British history.
Michael "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who also writes weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has also worked as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 residents in its administrative center and a metropolitan population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series *Make It or Break It* ended with its third and final season, announced on April 26, 2012, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, integrating linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. It is used in applications like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, and aviation. Recent progress stems from the adoption of deep learning by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, and Apple.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, in 1970. He served as its chairman starting that year, alongside co-founders Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
*Fist of Legend* is a remake of the 1972 film *Fist of Fury*, which originally starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par, while Rory McIlroy and Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat are one shot behind at 15 under. McIlroy, returning from an ankle injury, shot a third consecutive 67 and is aiming for his first title since May and a third Race to Dubai title. He overcame early mistakes in his round with a strong back nine, including an eagle on the 13th hole. Chris Wood and Richard Bland, previously tied for second, are now fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for the Bahraini government to offer "concrete solutions" for dialogue with the opposition to be meaningful. He expressed support for dialogue with reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, despite opposition from hardliners within the royal family. Salman noted that a previous agreement with the crown prince on reforms was undermined by the arrival of Gulf Co-operation Council troops. He criticized the lack of strong public stances from the US and UK on Bahrain's human rights issues and urged public pressure. He reaffirmed al-Wefaq’s commitment to peaceful protests and called for the release of 13 jailed opposition figures, warning that dialogue would fail without their inclusion.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it globally for 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His acclaimed 1980 recording of Handel's *Messiah* earned top recognition from BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood held academic roles at institutions like Harvard and Cambridge and directed festivals and music societies. Tributes highlighted his generosity, intelligence, and lasting influence on historical music performance. His funeral will be private, with a memorial to follow.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicides—the lowest since 1976 and half the number from nine years prior, with only one case unresolved. Sharp instruments, mainly knives, were used in 51% of the cases. About 31% of accused individuals were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted ongoing efforts to reduce violence through education, enforcement, and community support. However, Labour’s Claire Baker urged caution, noting past data revisions and rising violent and sexual crimes. The 2014–15 homicide count was revised from 59 to 62 after reclassification.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to be defeated by them in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling gave Bournemouth an early lead, marking their first goal in three games. Despite creating many chances, they were unable to score again, even after Sunderland were reduced to 10 men. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over missed opportunities but emphasized the importance of moving forward.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended his government's controversial policy of detaining boat-arriving migrants in offshore camps, stating that stopping the boats is necessary to prevent deaths at sea. The New York Times criticized the policy as inhumane and legally questionable. Abbott also sparked backlash from Jewish groups after comparing ISIS unfavorably to the Nazis, a remark deemed inappropriate by community leaders. Despite criticism, Abbott maintained his stance on both issues.
