The United States blamed Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, leading to the suspension of bilateral talks. The US cited Russia's failure to uphold commitments to a ceasefire, including attacks on hospitals and an aid convoy. In response, Russia denied the accusations and accused the US of not meeting its obligations, including separating jihadist groups from moderate opposition. As a result, planned cooperation on air strikes was halted, though both countries will continue discussions to prevent conflict during counter-terrorism operations.

The report by think tank Policy Exchange, supported by Downing Street, proposes selling vacant high-value social homes to raise £4.5bn annually, potentially funding the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes and significantly reducing the 1.8 million-person housing waiting list. The plan, intended to improve housing efficiency and stimulate the economy, faces criticism from Labour and others, who argue it could displace low-income families and create segregated communities. While government officials highlight ongoing reforms and investments in affordable housing, opponents warn of a detrimental impact on mixed communities and accessibility in high-cost areas.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea amid a measles outbreak with 942 reported cases. While lab tests confirmed he had measles, the exact cause of death is still undetermined, pending further tests and an inquest. He had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash after discharge. Despite no known exposure in his family, including his vaccinated daughter, he was diagnosed with measles before his sudden death.
Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, reportedly occurring in 2001. He is set to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley played to a 1-1 draw in a National League match. Guiseley took an early lead through Jake Lawlor in the 15th minute, despite Gateshead's dominance. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York following a defensive slip. Gateshead extended their unbeaten run to nine matches, while Guiseley remained unbeaten in five. The game featured several substitutions and yellow cards for players on both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to redevelop its current football stadium by replacing two stands to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is delayed due to a town green application. The redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed work could begin in May, pending the outcome of a six-week judicial review period.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations in Lancashire as a precaution following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is analyzing data from the event, which it linked to a similar 2.3 magnitude quake in April, both occurring near the Preese Hall site. Fracking, which involves injecting pressurized fluids into shale rock to extract gas, has raised environmental concerns, though UK officials argue proper regulation could mitigate issues. Cuadrilla plans to consult experts before deciding on next steps, while the BGS continues to monitor the area.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for displaying a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner while performing in April 2015, which gave the impression he was collecting donations for the charity. He was cleared of two other fraud charges. Although he claimed he was only busking and not soliciting funds, the court found otherwise. He had previously been given permission to display a banner as a tribute, not for fundraising. Sentencing is scheduled for January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3–0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (after a goalkeeping error by Alex Smithies), and Tom Lawrence. Ipswich, previously struggling to score, created several other chances and dominated the match. QPR were weak in attack, with their best effort being a late header by Sandro that hit the post. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th, above QPR who dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his players, while QPR boss Ian Holloway blamed poor defending and called for mental toughness from his team.

Wells, 23, had a strong T20 Blast season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He praised the club's positive direction and elite performance environment fostered by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams led a strong front-line effort with over 70 tackles. Despite the win, coach Churcher sees room for improvement and emphasizes the need to build on the performance. The Reds' upcoming schedule includes seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu and believed to be a Bangladeshi citizen, raped a 74-year-old nun during a March attack on a convent in Ranaghat, India. He was arrested in Kolkata after being identified from CCTV footage. The incident led to national outrage and protests. Nazrul is the sixth person arrested out of eight suspects, with two still at large. Other arrested suspects identified Nazrul as the rapist. During the attack, money was stolen, and the convent was ransacked.

The interactive video features Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands in London, discussing why consumer buying habits change, influenced by factors like domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also explores shifts in brand ownership and rankings in the UK. A non-interactive version and additional related content are available for those using older browsers.

Two women were scammed in separate incidents by callers posing as BT employees, who gained remote access to their computers and stole money. The first incident in Sandyhills occurred on 15 September, followed by another in Stranraer a week later. Police warn against giving out banking details over the phone and advise caution when receiving cold calls.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract to coach third-placed Championship team Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, a former player with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, is also an assistant coach for Scotland. At Swinton, he is succeeded by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard helicopter responded to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT Sunday to assist an unconscious rider with head injuries and hypothermia, who was later flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, over 160 countries agreed to allocate radio spectrum for global satellite-based flight tracking to improve upon current radar systems. Prompted by the 2014 disappearance of flight MH370, this move enables real-time aircraft tracking via satellite reception of ADS-B signals. The ITU acted swiftly to address air navigation gaps, with the ICAO setting a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring position updates every 15 minutes or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, was found at age 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby was arrested and charged, including tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012. The FBI confirmed Julian’s identity after college application issues raised suspicion. Authorities had long suspected the father, who took Julian under the pretense of going to pre-school. He is being held in Ohio on $250,000 bail.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site led to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, operated by Asset and Land Group, from accepting waste and decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. Although the site was broadly compliant with fire safety laws, the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had raised concerns about potential risks prior to the fire. The cause of the fire remains unknown, and the company must still remove all waste from the site.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two new bills in response to the Ukraine crisis, particularly focusing on Crimea. One bill would allow Russian annexation of foreign territories without a treaty if local leaders or referendums request it, especially in cases where a state is disintegrating. The second bill would ease and speed up the process for Ukrainians, especially Russian-speaking individuals, to obtain Russian citizenship, removing key requirements and shortening the wait time. These legislative moves align with Russia's past actions in Georgia’s breakaway regions and aim to strengthen support for pro-Russian sentiments in Ukraine.

The passage outlines the rise, fall, and hopeful resurgence of the McLaren Formula 1 team. Once dominant, with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' titles, and 8 constructors' championships, McLaren is now struggling, currently aiming only for mid-grid finishes. Their decline began in 2013 with chassis issues, now compounded by a weak Honda engine. Despite recent poor results, the team still boasts top drivers, including Fernando Alonso. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of success and decline, with past revivals led by Ron Dennis, who now aims to restore the team's glory. While the team believes a comeback is imminent, for now, all they have is belief.

Thomas "Tommy" Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest after leaving Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital. Police believe the attackers waited outside the gym for about an hour. Three local men have been arrested and remain in custody. Authorities are seeking a silver VW Polo seen fleeing the scene and are appealing for potential witnesses caught on CCTV.

The passage explores how technology is being used to celebrate and share the Christmas story in modern and digital ways. It highlights:

1. **Everyday Church Online** offers virtual Sunday services with global participation and Christmas sermons themed around *Star Wars*.
2. **Guardians of Ancora**, a free Bible-themed mobile game for children, includes quests about Jesus’ birth.
3. Viral videos like *The Digital Story of Nativity* and *Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle* creatively retell the Nativity online, although religious ads face screening challenges.
4. **Next Manga** has adapted Bible stories, including the Nativity, into Manga format, available as apps and e-books and distributed globally, including to refugees.
5. Churches use social media to connect communities and encourage spiritual reflection, with pastors asserting Jesus would be active on platforms like Twitter.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered. Experts disagree on the project's environmental impact. Natural Resources Wales questioned the replacement land's value but did not oppose the plan, while developers claimed a biodiversity gain, a claim disputed by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate will make a recommendation before Welsh ministers decide on the project's approval.

In April, Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a Novaya Gazeta report exposing the detention and alleged torture of over 100 suspected homosexual men in Chechnya, calling it an insult to their faith. The clerics’ resolution threatened "retribution," which the newspaper interpreted as a threat against its journalists. Despite denials from Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and officials, the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the abuses and is aiding victims. Novaya Gazeta's editor defended the report and called for dialogue. The case recalls past journalist murders linked to Chechnya. The LGBT Network warns it may take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and the charity Fresh Start Housing have been involved in housing single homeless men in London, often generating significant profits through housing benefit claims. While both entities operate legally, critics argue their model prioritizes profit over care, citing poor housing conditions. Investing Solutions places multiple tenants in single homes and claims individual housing benefits, leading to higher payouts than actual rent. Both organizations operate from the same building and were founded by Samir Patel. Fresh Start refers clients to both private landlords and Investing Solutions. Wandsworth Council alone paid over £2.1 million to the agency in two years. Despite providing housing to hundreds of homeless individuals, concerns have been raised about housing standards and motives.

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 in Great Britain’s final warm-up game before Eurobasket qualifiers. Despite leading for most of the game, GB lost to the Netherlands, who were led by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of consistent effort and praised Gordon’s third-quarter performance. GB opens their qualifying campaign in Hungary later in the week.

Former five-weight world champion Floyd Mayweather and UFC lightweight champion Conor McGregor are set to fight in a highly anticipated boxing match. Mayweather submitted a required waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to potentially use lighter 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz for their 154 lb bout, with the NAC to debate the decision on 16 August. McGregor, making his boxing debut, supports the glove change, while the NAC emphasizes fighter safety. The bout has faced criticism but was approved by NAC based on McGregor's past performances and physical attributes. Veteran referee Joe Cortez was brought in to help McGregor adjust to boxing rules.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, has seen the closure of its last newspaper office with the Sunday Post shutting down operations there. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for decades on Fleet Street, reflect on its history and decline. At its peak, Fleet Street housed nearly every major British newspaper and was known for its lively atmosphere filled with journalists and pubs. Technological advances, such as computerized printing and the move of newspapers to other locations (notably by Rupert Murdoch in the 1980s), led to its decline. The area has since been repurposed for other uses, marking the end of an iconic chapter in media history.

J.K. Rowling discussed facing online abuse for her political views, particularly after donating £1 million to oppose Scottish independence. She defended her right to speak out, saying she believes in confronting bullies and refuses to hide abusive behavior to protect political parties. While some SNP supporters were hostile, she also had positive interactions with others. Rowling acknowledged the SNP's major electoral success, humorously responding to extreme criticism.

A University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are significantly more likely to face police action, statutory supervision, and become involved in crime, with poverty increasing both victimization and perpetration rates. Boys are generally more prone to violence, but poverty also heightens violence among girls. A record of police involvement strongly predicts a lack of education or employment by age 18. Despite declining national crime rates, high-crime levels persist in the most deprived areas. Researchers argue that current systems may worsen conditions in poor communities. The Scottish government asserts crime has dropped and that it is investing to combat poverty and inequality.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody. Two others were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged Walsh and two others entered the estate looking for Haugh, encountered him, and a fight involving weapons broke out. Haugh was stabbed in the back, later died at hospital, and weapons including knives and golf clubs were recovered. The case has caused local tensions.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a false and defamatory statement about Tom Elliott regarding his past service in the UDR. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan later apologized, admitting it was untrue and baseless. The High Court heard Elliott had a clear MoD record and was notified about the tweet by public figures. Elliott, now an MP, expressed vindication and frustration over the delay in resolution. The court is yet to decide on compensation, and Flanagan is pursuing separate legal action after his indemnity insurer refused to cover the case.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has increased sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 units per week due to higher demand. The growth is driven by strong sales of its new branded range launched in January and continued success in private label supply. Owned by managing director Benny Hartop since November last year, the company exports to several European countries and markets worldwide, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's car outside a school in Kempston. Wright, 55, admitted hitting her but denies dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn was escorting pedestrians across the road when Wright failed to stop at a red light. She is now in residential care, and the trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose", conducted in response to increased Russian submarine activity. A German U-boat, U33, simulates the enemy, evading detection by ten NATO warships and aircraft. The exercise highlights the difficulty of locating submarines and the growing threat posed by Russia’s advanced and stealthy submarine fleet. It also underscores a major gap in the UK’s defenses—its lack of maritime patrol aircraft—requiring reliance on allies for surveillance. Experts warn that this vulnerability could allow Russian subs to track British nuclear assets undetected, stressing the need for enhanced UK defense capabilities.

Since violence erupted in South Sudan in July, over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, surpassing the number of Syrian refugees this year. Daily, 2,500 South Sudanese seek refuge due to killings, rape, and ethnic targeting, especially by the Dinka against Equatorians and Nuer. The conflict, originally between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer ex-Vice President Riek Machar, has expanded into ethnic violence. Refugees describe horrific journeys and atrocities. Uganda has responded generously, offering land and aid, but is strained by the influx. The UN urges international action to stop the civilian massacres in South Sudan.

Leon McKenzie, 38, is set to fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer who turned professional boxer in 2013, McKenzie has an unbeaten record of eight wins and one draw. He is the son of ex-champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330 million government investment in NHS facilities across England. Costing £33 million, the hospital will be funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. It will replace the outdated 1813-built facility and feature 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, minor injury unit, X-ray equipment, and space for mobile scanners. The new hospital aims to improve patient care and support recovery. Construction depends on planning approval, with completion targeted for autumn 2014. This project is part of broader healthcare upgrades in Somerset, including the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital.

A man was fatally shot near a black Mercedes on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield. Police were called at 13:35 GMT and found him with a chest wound; he later died in hospital. The victim was reportedly linked to a nearby family gathering. This incident follows a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, though previous ones occurred in the city's north, not Upperthorpe.

The passage discusses three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine-Russia conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, carry out DDoS attacks, hack into Russian systems, and use hijacked cameras and printers to support Ukraine, sharing findings with security services and activist group Inform Napalm. Cyber Berkut is a pro-Russian group opposing Ukraine and the West, targeting Ukrainian government sites and spreading propaganda during key events. Anonymous International leaks Kremlin-related documents, focusing on Russian domestic issues, with some material on Ukraine, though their sources are unclear.

Several veteran Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), including Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie, gave emotional farewell speeches ahead of stepping down before the 5 May election. Alex Salmond reflected on Scotland's diversity and parliamentary progress, expressed support for more devolved powers, and added humor to his address. Duncan McNeil emphasized the need for improved accountability in Holyrood, suggesting it could learn from Westminster. Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by the departures, and praised Salmond’s service. Annabel Goldie also delivered a light-hearted farewell, noting her interactions with colleagues.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care in residential care homes for older people in Wales. She is gathering input from residents, their families, care staff, and public bodies to develop recommendations for improvements. The review aims to highlight both good and poor care experiences and will assess various factors affecting quality of life. While the review is supported by Care Forum Wales, its chair, Mario Kreft, criticizes the exclusion of care home providers from the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company saw international sales growth in Europe and new markets and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland serving rural communities. Harbro manufactures animal feeds and acknowledges ongoing challenges in agriculture and Brexit uncertainty but remains confident in its future position.

A man in his 70s was found dead in a house in Little Gaddesden, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the case. Authorities have warned the public not to approach him and have provided a description of his appearance. Additional police patrols are being conducted to reassure residents.

David Lipton, IMF's second-in-command, warned of a weakening global economy, citing disappointing Chinese trade data with exports down 25% year-on-year. He indicated that the IMF would likely lower its global growth forecast from 3.4% in April, highlighting continued risks, particularly for businesses dependent on China’s growth.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with a new chain ferry that has faced multiple problems since its delayed launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and training-related suspensions. In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July and an auditor review of the project. Local businesses reported significant trade losses and called for compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the issues but described them as teething problems of a prototype, noting that some technical and operational problems have been resolved, including ramp modifications. Compensation discussions are ongoing.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has come under fire for job adverts specifying physical attributes like hair color and bra size, which critics say are sexist and unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's rights groups condemned these practices as demeaning and discriminatory. Employment experts warned the ads could lead to legal action for sex or age discrimination. The agency's founder defended the criteria as client-driven, citing specific aesthetic requests. Despite serving high-profile clients, critics urge the company to modernize its hiring practices.

A rare school shooting occurred at a hostel of Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where office assistant Mahesh allegedly shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. The motive remains unclear.

GLAAD's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, including a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also noted a record high percentage of Black characters on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like *Empire*, *Luke Cage*, and *How to Get Away with Murder*. GLAAD emphasized that while progress is being made, numbers tell only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not seek re-election amid criticism over a missing £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC during his time as council leader. The loan, intended for stadium redevelopment, is under police investigation. Facing likely deselection by his local party, Mackintosh denied any wrongdoing but chose to step down.

In April, Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas. Initially, police claimed the car was reversing aggressively, but footage later showed it was driving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. He is currently out on bail, with no trial date set. If convicted, he could face 5 to 99 years in prison and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

Melania Trump’s decision to delay moving into the White House with son Barron until he finishes the school year sparked criticism and speculation, though some supported it as a responsible parenting choice. Historically, only two First Ladies did not live in the White House, and delays for children’s schooling are not unprecedented. Melania has emphasized Barron as her priority and may not take on a full-time First Lady role like Michelle Obama. The role of the First Lady is traditionally ceremonial but has evolved into a visible, influential position. Other family members, like daughters or daughters-in-law, have occasionally assumed First Lady responsibilities.

A 72-year-old man died on 27 October in Inverness. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to his call, following instructions from the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS). Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning was issued due to gusts up to 75mph, especially west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction possibly worsening the impact. Travel disruptions are expected in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. In Anglesey, strong winds brought down a tree in Menai Bridge, closing Telford Road, which will likely remain closed for much of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants and Panthers played a closely contested game, ending with a 4-3 win for the Giants. Key scorers included Derrick Walser, Mike Forney, Mike Radja, and James Desmarais for the Giants, while Jeff Dimmen, Andy Bohmback, and David Ling scored for the Panthers. The teams will play again on Saturday. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield (27) and Belfast (25).

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered early damage, made five pit stops, and finished behind Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth despite a first-lap collision with teammate Sebastian Vettel. Vettel finished second, while Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo took podium spots behind race winner Nico Rosberg, who benefited from a strong start and early race chaos. Hamilton now trails Rosberg by 36 points in the championship, with Ferrari’s tire strategy aiding Raikkonen’s late-race performance. Post-race, Vettel confronted Kvyat over a risky move, and Hamilton’s car damage significantly impacted his race.

Former German footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit to spark dialogue on homosexuality in football, a topic often ignored in Germany. As the most prominent footballer to do so, his announcement received widespread praise from former teammates, football officials, public figures, and politicians, highlighting its significance in combating homophobia. The move is considered a landmark moment, with hopes it will encourage more openness and acceptance in the sport.

Steve Sidwell, 34, played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton (the Seagulls) secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring, he hopes to sign a new deal and continue with the team. Previously on loan from Stoke before signing a one-year contract in 2016, Sidwell has Premier League experience with several clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level. Brighton won promotion with a recent victory over Wigan and aim to secure the league title with two games remaining.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in a match where both teams missed several key chances. Jamille Matt gave Blackpool an early lead, but Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester shortly after. Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made several crucial saves, including stops on George Elokobi and Guthrie before halftime. Tom Aldred missed a late chance to win it for Blackpool, and Colchester ended the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season before their relegation from League One. He may debut for Colchester United in their upcoming EFL Cup match against Aston Villa, following Colchester's 3-1 loss to Accrington in their season opener.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer highlighted the need for a permanent UK police memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust launched a £1.5 million appeal for its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire. The £4 million project, partially funded by a £1 million government contribution, will honor over 1,400 fallen officers and staff with a brass screen featuring cut-out leaf shapes as personal tributes. The memorial, recognizing 250 years of service, is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League after a 1-0 win over Sunderland, with eight games left to surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record from 2005. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson praised the team’s record of 25 wins in 30 matches and emphasized focus on the upcoming derby against Manchester City. Injuries were sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, prompting planned changes for the upcoming FA Cup replay at Chelsea. Key players Rooney, Welbeck, and Cleverley were rested, and others like Giggs and Hernandez will return for the next match.

Mr. Schmidt defended Google’s UK tax practices, stating the company met all legal obligations, paying £10m in corporate taxes from 2006 to 2011, and emphasized that tax law changes are the government's responsibility. He argued companies should pay what is legally required and welcomed clearer international tax rules. In response to criticism over tax avoidance, Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to examine corporate tax arrangements confidentially. EU leaders agreed to strengthen oversight through automatic information exchange, while Schmidt advocated for corporate taxes to be based on where economic activity occurs.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce NHS spending on agency staff by £1bn after £3.6bn was spent last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m, limiting staff pay to 55% above normal rates (excluding senior managers). Though progress is "promising," NHS trusts are still 10% behind their target, and it's unclear if other staffing costs have risen. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables and collect data on top-earning agency staff to increase transparency and control costs.

The Longford Town Centre, once emblematic of Ireland’s economic boom, now symbolizes its downturn. However, local traders like Matt O’Brien are seeing signs of recovery, with efforts to diversify businesses helping growth. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government’s neglect of the midlands, citing poor investment in infrastructure and IDA inaction. In contrast, the government highlights the planned Center Parcs resort expected to create 1,000 jobs by 2019, pending planning approval. While hopeful, locals stress that more support—such as free parking—could further boost the economy. Overall, recovery has begun but greater efforts are needed.

The competition concludes on 29 May in the same stadium, featuring eight teams each playing twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key performers include Warner (294 runs, 12 sixes), Kohli (267 runs, 8 sixes), De Villiers (249 runs, 12 sixes), and De Kock (highest single score of 108). McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7) lead in wickets. Four England players participating are Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. Fixtures run from 25 April to 22 May, followed by play-offs and the final.

Since 2013, plastic bag use in England increased by 200 million, causing environmental harm due to their limited recyclability. Starting in October, a 5p charge will be introduced in England to encourage reuse, following similar successful measures in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Campaigners hope this will reduce waste and help the environment.

High winds caused significant disruption across Wales, including part of a school roof being torn off, widespread power cuts, and travel delays. A yellow weather warning was in place, affecting roads, rail, ferries, and prompting the closure of National Trust sites. Winds eased by Friday evening, lifting some travel restrictions, but the blustery forecast led to the postponement of at least one festive event.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about a new film project, reuniting with Creed director Ryan Coogler for Black Panther, set for release in February 2018. He looks forward to working with co-stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan did not reveal his role, but noted past roles in Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o and Boseman have acclaimed performances in Star Wars and Captain America: Civil War, respectively.

The east wing of Alexandra Palace, including the historic 1875 theatre and BBC studios, is undergoing a £26.6m restoration to become a cultural destination featuring performances, exhibitions, and public spaces. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades but retaining original features, is hoped to reopen in 2018.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior caps for England since his debut in 2009 and participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing briefly at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 since 2004 and scored his only international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her young son David, who was the only one awake and noticed the flames. The fire, started by rubbish in a wood stove, quickly engulfed the home, destroying it and killing their pets. The smoke alarm did not go off. Despite fleeing in pyjamas, the community has supported them with donations. Marcy credits David with saving their lives and is proud of his bravery.

The energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m bid for Premier League club West Ham, which Sullivan and Gold acquired majority control of in 2010 when the club was valued at £105m. They now own over 85% and have faced takeover interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium. Sullivan previously mentioned a minority share could be sold to clear debts, but they plan to pass ownership to their children.

The event, described as "definitely not the Oscars" by Jillian Bell, was a fan-voted awards ceremony featuring unique categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance. *The Fault in Our Stars* was the big winner, earning best movie, with Shailene Woodley taking best female performance, best kiss, and the Trailblazer Award. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for *American Sniper*, and Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for *22 Jump Street*. Meryl Streep was awarded best villain, while other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award, honoring his children. Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, presented by his fellow Avengers co-stars. The event also promoted upcoming films like *Pitch Perfect 2*, *Trainwreck*, and *Avengers: Ultron*.

Cammy Smith, 21, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. He previously made 89 appearances and scored four goals for Aberdeen since his 2012 debut. St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a valuable and mature addition to his team, providing more attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, are set to play Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council plans to use Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily over four months due to improved weather. Additional staff will fix rain-damaged drainage systems and clear gutter debris.

In December, six Wood Group contractors on EnQuest’s Thistle platform near Shetland were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation (NORM) during shutdown work. They had been working without proper protective gear, unaware of the radiation risk. Steve Innes, a rigging supervisor, raised concerns about the company’s safety procedures and reported ongoing health fears and difficulty finding further work. EnQuest said the exposure was below reportable levels but took precautionary steps and informed the HSE. Wood Group emphasized employee safety and supported a joint investigation. The Unite union criticized the handling of the incident, while the HSE confirmed it was informed but did not investigate due to regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari in 2007 for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past. Later, the dealer's manager admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, believed to have been taken from a temple in Tamil Nadu. Following a request by India's Archaeological Survey and discussions with Singapore’s National Heritage Board, the ACM decided to return the piece. While there is no definitive proof of theft, the museum cited the dealer's confession and plans to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. Felt as far as Milan and Florence, the quake caused no immediate injuries or damage, though phone and power outages occurred, and schools were evacuated. Several aftershocks followed. Italy is earthquake-prone, and in 2009, nearly 300 people died in L'Aquila. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter for downplaying warnings before that quake.

Austin Grant from Sheffield was initially doubtful about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, but he has now successfully grown fruit, although it is not yet ripe. He expressed great excitement over the achievement.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of Grand Theft Auto V to 24 March, from the original date of 27 January, to allow more time for testing and improvements. They assured fans the wait will be worthwhile. Online heists will debut on consoles prior to the PC launch. Rockstar also released PC screenshots, promising enhanced detail, 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor support. Minimum PC specifications have been shared. The game originally launched on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product in history, earning $1 billion in just three days.

76-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his artwork Squint (19), having previously been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three times. The painting, depicting a leper squint in medieval churches, was praised by judge Ansel Krut as “extraordinary” and technically subtle. Simpson said the work is part of a larger series and chose to submit it due to its manageable size and his familiarity with it. He plans to use the prize money on high-quality art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards.

The offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday by masked assailants, with no reported casualties. Both buildings sustained gunfire damage, and police are investigating the incidents. No group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player, previously on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 games, will join the Mariners on a free transfer from the Stags on 1 January, becoming Marcus Bignot's first signing.

Arsène Wenger, whose club contract ends in the summer, has been linked to the England manager job but stated he is focused on his current role. He praised current interim manager Gareth Southgate, highlighting his competency and chance to prove himself in upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger also addressed transfer rumors surrounding Hector Bellerin, confirming Arsenal plans to offer him a new contract despite interest from other clubs. Additionally, Aaron Ramsey remains sidelined with a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will resolve a dispute over low seafarer pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had criticized wages below £4 an hour on two boats run by Seatruck, contracted by Serco Northlink. The new agreement will return service control to Serco Northlink, ensuring all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. The change is expected next month, pending final financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink holds a £243m, six-year contract subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May following an altercation at Rockley Park involving Jamie Mitchell, 35, who intervened in a dispute between Dickie and Mitchell's mother. The confrontation occurred after heavy drinking, and Mitchell later admitted to common assault and, along with his mother, to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police. Both will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter renowned for his work with Michael Jackson and the band Heatwave, died in London at age 66 after a short battle with cancer. He wrote major hits like "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Off the Wall," and contributed to making *Thriller* the best-selling album in U.S. history. Originally from Cleethorpes, Temperton first gained fame in the 1970s with Heatwave before catching the attention of producer Quincy Jones. He also wrote for artists such as Aretha Franklin and Donna Summer, won a Grammy in 1990, and received two Oscar nominations in 1986. Known for his low profile, Temperton was widely praised by fellow musicians after his death.

Researchers, including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, concealed for centuries by rainforest until deforestation revealed them. Likely built around 2,000 years ago, their purpose remains unclear, though they may have served as ritual gathering sites. Soil analysis and plant fossils suggest they were constructed within tall vegetation, unlike other visible ritual sites. The findings challenge the belief that pre-European Amazon forests were untouched, showing humans manipulated plant diversity over 6,000 years, creating a form of prehistoric agroforestry that may still influence today's biodiversity.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Coming off a win at the Japan Open, Kyrgios admitted feeling tired and less vocal during the match due to travel fatigue and poor sleep. He also noted the long commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium. Last year at the same tournament, he was fined for inappropriate behavior.

Scientists and health organizations are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination to boys, citing rising cases of head and neck cancers, especially among men. HPV is sexually transmitted and currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to prevent cervical cancer. Charities and researchers argue that expanding the program would help reduce the broader cancer burden. While 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated since 2008, the government is awaiting guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, died from a rare cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He shared his journey and positive outlook through a Facebook page, “Jak’s Journey,” which gained over 28,000 followers. Despite his illness, he briefly attended a prom held in his honour and received awards recognizing his resilience. His story touched many, and following his death, his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A charity football match was planned to raise more funds in his memory.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a tightly contested match thanks to an 89th-minute goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The game featured few chances, with Salah and El Said among the key contributors. Earlier, Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside, and despite a promising start to the second half, they failed to register a shot on target. The win keeps Egypt in contention for the top spot in Group D ahead of their final group match against Ghana, who have already qualified for the quarter-finals. Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament appearance since 1978.

Lancashire County Council has proposed building a new railway station in Skelmersdale, considering sites including the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College. Glenburn is the preferred location due to its size, accessibility, and potential for expansion. The plan, developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, includes two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Skelmersdale, a designated new town since 1961, has lacked a railway station since 1956. The council will begin acquiring the necessary land.
Police discovered an "elaborate grow house" with plants in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was seriously injured after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, from Bad Muender, later turned himself in to police. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The woman underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Authorities are still investigating the motive and have called for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, using data from 4,600 Australian workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for pay rises but are 25% less likely to receive them. The research debunks the “reticent female” theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking due to fear of upsetting their boss or gender stereotypes. The study controlled for factors like job type, employer size, and parental status. It also found that men and women under 40 receive raises at similar rates, suggesting a shift in negotiating behavior. Researchers suggest discrimination may explain the disparities.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, spending funds on ground investigations, but has not found any suitable land due to issues like poor ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Once full, options will be limited to reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes. The last expansion in burial space occurred in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway (19–22 July) can use an app to access online content like videos and band interviews by scanning items on-site. Acts include The Waterboys and Imelda May. The augmented reality feature aims to enhance the experience and allow global interaction with the festival.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died from a rare severe pulmonary haemorrhage after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Despite past issues with overheating and post-race ataxia, he showed no such symptoms before this race. The British Horseracing Authority emphasized that such incidents are rare and not necessarily linked to underlying health issues. His death has prompted calls for further research into the causes and prevention of such occurrences. Many Clouds had a successful career, previously winning the Gold Cup trial (2015) and Hennessy Gold Cup (2014).

A 34-year-old defendant, now called Davina Ayrton, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The victim reported remembering the event clearly and later disclosed it to a care home worker in 2014. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and has not undergone physical gender transition, denied the charge. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely in a male prison, citing risks of self-harm and failure to appear. Sentencing is scheduled for March 4.

Serbian tennis players lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This followed Novak Djokovic’s singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, ranked world number one, had also been defeated in Wimbledon’s third round by Sam Querrey but later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors will participate in a chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge, where only chainsaws are allowed to carve logs into animals and people. Participants come from the UK, Europe, Canada, and the US. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, out since September due to a foot injury, is nearing a return and hopes to be fit by the Six Nations in February. The 27-year-old is currently in a pre-season phase and may return earlier than expected. He has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region and continue aiming to play for Wales.

U.S. border agents near Sumas, Washington, intercepted an attempt to smuggle 58 pounds of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. During the encounter, one suspect, Nathan Hall, fled after firing at officers but was later arrested; the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was detained immediately. Two additional suspects, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to transport the drugs, with Lambert allegedly offered $11,000 for delivery. All three U.S. detainees face conspiracy and drug charges. The area is known for frequent drug and firearms smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reports a significant rise in counselling cases related to online abuse, with over 4,500 children helped in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. Online bullying affects many children, some as young as seven, causing fear, humiliation, and mental distress. Childline’s president, Dame Esther Rantzen, urges adults and schools to intervene, emphasizing that bullying worsens if ignored. The findings are released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance to raise awareness and combat bullying through collaboration with parents, schools, and organizations.

The passage discusses escalating tensions between Israel and the United States following the U.S. decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution that condemned Israeli settlement construction as illegal under international law. The resolution, particularly critical of building in East Jerusalem, was strongly rejected by Israel, prompting Prime Minister Netanyahu to take diplomatic actions against countries that supported it. Alleging U.S. involvement in the resolution’s drafting, Netanyahu’s office requested a postponement of a vote on new settlements to avoid further conflict ahead of a speech by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian issue. Kerry is expected to present his vision for peace and respond to Israeli criticisms, while Palestinian President Abbas supports the resolution and upcoming peace conference in France.

The passage discusses celebrations for Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, highlighting her public appearances, tribute events, and commemorative stamp releases. Prince William praised the Queen as a model monarch and addressed recent media criticism of his royal duties, stating he is committed but finding his own path. The Queen's visit to Windsor marked the postal service's 500th anniversary, and she participated in unveiling The Queen’s Walkway. The day concluded with a beacon lighting ceremony, and President Obama was set to join her for lunch the following day. Some criticized the BBC's coverage as overly celebratory and unbalanced.

West Ham United defeated League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Despite Cheltenham's bright start, early goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew gave West Ham control before halftime. Cheltenham, unchanged from a recent loss, had chances but failed to seriously test goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham, who made seven changes after Premier League losses, could have won by a larger margin. The result ended League Two’s representation in the competition before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a crash on the A5 caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who turned his vehicle without seeing the motorcyclist. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family did not seek a jail sentence, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse but had no explanation for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from west London, traveled to Syria in early 2014 where he joined the IS-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. Known for masked online propaganda promoting jihad, he appeared in videos and images, including one where he posed with a severed head. The group used slick media to attract young British Muslims. Khawaja later attempted to secretly return to the UK, faking his death and entering the country with help from his cousin, Tahir Bhatti. He was arrested upon arrival and has since admitted to four offences. Authorities consider him a highly dangerous individual because of his actions and deception.

Kayden Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, has joined Barnsley as their third signing ahead of their League One play-off final. He turned down a contract from Wrexham and is praised by caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom for his pace and attacking style.

Bottles, believed to contain detergent, began washing up at Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish beaches following stormy weather. The National Trust suspects they came from a container lost overboard by a ship, possibly the MV Blue Ocean, though this link is unconfirmed. Most bottles are sealed, but some have leaked, raising environmental concerns. Conservationists warn of risks to marine life, and local authorities are monitoring the situation and advising the public to avoid the bottles.

A crash occurred at about 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, causing minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship. He has been with the club since 2014, making 83 appearances. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his late-season contributions. Dervite has signed a new contract, joining teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in renewing their deals.

The passage describes a breakdown in cooperation between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the House of Lords over Brexit amendments. Initially united in challenging the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval of the Brexit deal, the parties split after MPs rejected the amendments—Labour deferred to the Commons, while the Lib Dems insisted on them. Each party accused the other of either grandstanding or conceding too much. Despite past cooperation on various issues, tensions have risen, though both sides suggest future collaboration remains possible.

Defence has become a low political priority in the UK, with opinion polls ranking it far behind issues like the economy, NHS, and immigration. Political parties give minimal attention to defence in their manifestos, and military spending continues to be cut despite growing global threats such as Islamic extremism, failed states, and a more aggressive Russia. The UK's armed forces have been significantly reduced, leading to capability gaps like the absence of maritime patrol aircraft. Defence spending is projected to fall below Nato’s 2% GDP target, with only UKIP and the DUP pledging to meet that level. The MoD, with a large but unprotected budget, faces potential further cuts. Meanwhile, costly commitments like replacing Trident submarines pose budgetary challenges. There is no political consensus on the UK's nuclear deterrent, and future defence reviews may reconsider it. Though two new aircraft carriers are entering service, staffing and equipment limitations raise concerns about a "hollow force." Britain's ability to maintain its global military influence is increasingly in doubt.

Barcelona insists it committed no wrongdoing in Neymar’s transfer but made a complimentary tax payment of €13.55 million to address differing interpretations of tax obligations. The club originally claimed to have paid £48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost, including fees and wages, reached £106.8 million. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds and is under investigation. A judge ruled the case could proceed, and it remains uncertain whether Barcelona's payment will end the investigation. Neymar has scored ten goals for the club this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, an elderly driver going the wrong way. Luciw’s family is calling for mandatory driving tests and medical checks for older drivers. The crash occurred on 12 October near Kegworth, and Luciw was traveling for work with a colleague who also suffered injuries. While the DVLA currently requires drivers over 70 to self-assess every three years, there are no plans to impose stricter checks. Age UK emphasized supporting older people to drive safely as long as possible.

The passage discusses controversy surrounding an independent review of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse. Many women have reported severe side effects, leading to concerns about the implants' safety. Two patients and a consultant quit the review group, claiming the final report was diluted and parts were removed. Tracey Gillies, the chairwoman during the report’s final stages, acknowledged her failure to achieve consensus and faced public backlash. Professor Alison Britton will now review the report process to identify lessons for the future. The report recommended offering alternative treatments, ensuring informed patient choice, and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the Scottish government will continue implementing these recommendations, noting that the authority to ban lies with a UK regulatory body. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had the implants, with more than 400 pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Although McColgan initially questioned whether the race met record ratification criteria—due to Muir running alone and potential doping control concerns—British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be ratified. McColgan praised Muir's performance and potential, suggesting she could run even faster and win world medals. Muir previously broke her own British 1500m record and reached the Olympic 1500m final in 2016.

Jung won gold riding Sam, a late substitute after Fischertakinou fell ill. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt, returning from a serious injury, finished 12th after setbacks in the cross-country phase.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated Fabio Fognini in four sets (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) in a tense and dramatic match lasting two hours and 39 minutes, securing a place in the last 16 at Wimbledon for the 11th time. Despite Fognini's strong challenge and five set points in the fourth set, Murray rallied from 5-2 down to win five games in a row. He will face Benoit Paire next. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to week two for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar with evidence of alcohol service as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar closed for three months. License holder Colleen O'Neill was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside legal hours and fined £3,000. James Thomas faced one count and was fined £1,000. The bar was found to be poorly managed, with licensing laws not followed.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched the party's manifesto emphasizing partnership over domination and aiming to make the election a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. His comments about preferring post-election cooperation with the SDLP over Sinn Féin drew attention, including public distancing by colleague Danny Kennedy. Nesbitt stood by his remarks, expressing confidence in voter support and the party's platform, which includes reforms in health, policing, infrastructure, LGBT rights, and Brexit protections. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', also calls for cleaning up politics at Stormont.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, aligning with similar measures in England and Wales under 'Turing's Law'. The proposed motion includes both posthumous pardons and applications by living gay and bisexual men. Sugden emphasized the importance of equal treatment and the urgency of addressing past injustices through this legislative consent motion.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish mile record with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record. This performance placed her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m record, expressed excitement about her result and aims to qualify for the Olympics at the British trials in June. She recently began her season with an 800m win in France and is balancing her training with veterinary studies, having completed her fourth year.
The passage highlights that 26 beaches in Scotland have been ranked as "most excellent" for water quality and includes pictures of some of them.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state likely sponsored the 2006 murder using radioactive polonium-210. Litvinenko, who died weeks later, had defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of corruption and attacking President Putin, potentially providing motive. Though there’s no evidence President Putin directly ordered the killing, Horwell emphasized Russian state involvement. The suspects, who leave a trail of radioactive evidence and deny wrongdoing, remain in Russia after failed extradition attempts. The inquiry continues.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the captain of Australia's Twenty20 team in addition to already leading the one-day side, succeeding Michael Clarke who retired after the Ashes defeat. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues. National selector Rod Marsh praised both players, emphasizing Smith's talent and leadership potential, and noting Warner's maturity. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron repeatedly declined to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead emphasizing that "we are all sinners." Despite past criticism for voting against the 2007 Equality Bill, he asserted strong support for LGBT+ rights, promising to defend and expand equal marriage laws, particularly for transgender people. He cited concerns over individual liberties as the reason for opposing the bill and affirmed his commitment to legal equality regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now take over the site for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire former Sanofi staff. The move is expected to positively impact the local economy, with support from Newcastle’s city council. Accord is a global pharmaceutical company distributing over 130 products to around 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving the council at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn criticized the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipated more departures. Ellis was the interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive; Monaghan led the chief executive's office, and Sutherland headed human resources and customer services. Chief executive Angela Scott thanked them for their service.

English rider Guy Martin experienced mechanical issues with his Honda Fireblade and crashed at the TT, leading to a poor racing season. While initially suggesting he was quitting road racing, he later clarified he was only stepping back from racing Hondas for the year. Martin skipped the North West 200 and will not race in the Ulster Grand Prix, expressing frustration with the bike's performance and a lack of enjoyment. He now plans to focus on classic and unconventional races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorships in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the long-dominant Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which won only eight. This follows the PDP's loss of the presidency to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states and struggled to gain national support, performing mostly in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC gained Lagos and most northern states but failed to win in any of the oil-producing states. The elections saw some violence but were generally more peaceful than previous polls. The PDP, weakened by defections and accusations of corruption and security failures, now faces the challenge of rebuilding under new leadership.

A U.S.-based environmental group, Mighty, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main investor, Singapore's Temasek, of contributing to unsustainable palm oil practices that may worsen Southeast Asia’s haze problem. The report alleges Olam sources most of its palm oil from unverified third parties, potentially creating a hidden market for non-compliant producers, and raises similar concerns about deforestation in Gabon. Both Olam and Temasek deny the claims, emphasizing support for sustainable practices. Olam asserts it has a strict “no burn-no peat-no deforestation” policy and has begun disclosing its suppliers, while Temasek maintains it does not direct Olam's operations. The broader palm oil industry faces criticism for environmental damage, yet enforcement is difficult due to its economic importance.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at outdoor restaurant areas.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only played as a substitute recently. David Nugent may return after missing the previous game with a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is aiming for a recall after scoring as a substitute in the last match.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube following Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version, which allows the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request the blocking of content deemed offensive. While many young Pakistanis welcome the move, some activists call for transparency about the agreement with Google. YouTube maintains that content removal will follow its community guidelines and that not all government requests will be granted, with such requests logged in its Transparency Report. The original ban was imposed in 2012 after the controversial film *Innocence of Muslims* sparked deadly protests in Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, chair of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and a Swiss-Italian, is under pressure to step down due to sharing nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Liberian FA boss Musa Bility, denied election participation himself, cites FIFA regulations and previous precedents for members withdrawing to avoid conflicts of interest. Bility has threatened legal action if Scala does not withdraw before the 26 February election. Scala’s spokesman argues there is no current conflict, as there is no incumbent candidate. Five individuals, including Infantino and Prince Ali, are contesting to replace Sepp Blatter as FIFA president.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in a suspected flashover explosion while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road. Their bodies were recovered the following day. Forensic investigations and witness statements suggest the explosion was caused by a build-up of toxic fumes ignited, creating a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is conducting further evidence gathering with safety experts.

In the lead-up to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, Tunisia risked expulsion due to a dispute with the Confederation of African Football (Caf) over refereeing decisions in the 2015 tournament, but remained in after issuing an apology following a meeting with Caf leadership. Morocco, initially banned for withdrawing as 2015 hosts over Ebola fears, was reinstated after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced its fine. Tunisia was drawn into Group A and Morocco into Group F for the 2017 qualifiers. If Tunisia qualifies, it will mark their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

A mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute of Manchester City's 3-1 loss to Chelsea at Etihad Stadium, leading to red cards for City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho. Aguero received a four-match ban for a violent challenge, while Fernandinho was banned for three matches after a clash with Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Mae gan Gymru gyfraddau goroesi canser gwael, ac er mwyn mynd i’r afael â hyn, mae cynllun peilot wedi’i lansio yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd. Mae’r cynllun yn canolbwyntio ar gleifion sydd heb symptomau brys ond sydd o bosib â chanser. Bydd meddygon yn gallu cyfeirio’r cleifion hyn at ganolfan ddiagnostig o fewn saith diwrnod, gyda’r nod o gael diagnosis ar yr un diwrnod. Cafodd y syniad ei ysbrydoli gan systemau Denmarc, sydd wedi gwella cyfraddau goroesi. Mae’r cynllun yn ceisio cyflymu’r broses ddiagnostig a sicrhau triniaeth gynnar. Os bydd y treial chwe mis yn llwyddiannus, gallai’r gwasanaeth gael ei ymestyn i fyrddau iechyd eraill.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a dominant performance, leveling the series. Joe Root starred with a first innings score of 254, an unbeaten 71 in the second, four catches, and a wicket, earning man of the match. Captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s disciplined batting. England's comprehensive play, including strong batting and bowling, led to one of their biggest run-margin wins over Pakistan. In contrast, Pakistan struggled, with only two players passing 50 across two Tests. Captain Misbah acknowledged poor shot selection and low confidence but remained hopeful for a comeback.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley joining as interim coach. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will become Wales head coach for the third time during the summer tour, with assistant coaches to be appointed by the WRU. McBryde expressed enthusiasm for the role, having led tours in 2009 and 2013. WRU is finalizing the coaching team, and officials believe these experiences will benefit Welsh rugby long-term.

Hull City came from behind to defeat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak and securing their first league win since August 20. Charlie Austin put Southampton ahead with an early penalty, but Hull equalized through Robert Snodgrass and took the lead via Michael Dawson’s header, both goals coming within two minutes in the second half. Despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to injury early on, Hull's performance improved notably after Snodgrass entered the game. Southampton pushed for an equalizer, but David Marshall and Sam Clucas made crucial saves and clearances. Hull remain in the bottom three ahead of the international break.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash with a tractor around 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Thornton, close to Woodhall Spa. The victim was a local resident, while the tractor driver was unharmed. Police are seeking witnesses, and the road was closed between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into alleged government abuses revealed by covert recordings, aiming to end political turmoil before early elections. His decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who warned it jeopardizes Macedonia's EU aspirations. The crisis began in 2015 with recordings released by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, alleging government corruption, vote-rigging, and cover-ups. The government denies the claims and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country.

Swansea City's Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead the team against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis emphasizes the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if relegated and believes the club has declined since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. While acknowledging a loss of identity and insufficient player replacements, Curtis feels the current squad can still avoid relegation and stresses the importance of survival for the club and community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, ending their slim hopes of survival. The Daggers, who had reached League One in 2010 under manager John Still, struggled this season with the worst goal difference in League Two and poor offensive output. Jamie Cureton scored nine goals, down from 20 the previous season. Still, back for a third managerial stint, aims to lead the club back up. Leyton Orient's win, under interim boss Andy Hessenthaler following Kevin Nolan’s removal, keeps their play-off hopes alive.

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool and England captain, will return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach, marking his first role since retiring from a 19-year playing career. Jurgen Klopp praised the move and Gerrard's ambition to become a manager, noting he's ready to learn. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and won multiple major trophies, turned down a managerial role at MK Dons, saying it was too soon. He is also pursuing his UEFA A coaching licence.

Morton took an early lead with goals from McManus and Ross Forbes, and despite Alloa pulling one back through Kyle McAusland before half-time, further goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted found children being taught in squalid conditions at three now-closed sites in Birmingham, part of a wider investigation into 18 unregulated schools in the Midlands, mainly in Muslim communities. The government is considering tougher regulations for institutions teaching over 6 to 8 hours weekly, and running an illegal school could lead to prosecution and jail time.
