Amir Hamza was the top bowler with 2-23. Ireland missed paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back injury but expect him back for the ODIs starting 15 March. The teams will meet again in a second T20 match on Friday in Greater Noida.

Barcelona insists it committed no offense in Neymar's transfer, despite paying a total of £106.8m including fees and a recent tax payment of €13.55m to address possible differing tax interpretations. The initial reported fee was £48.6m, with £34m going to Neymar's parents. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid related allegations, and a Spanish judge ruled there is enough evidence to continue the investigation. Barcelona maintains its original tax payment was correct, and it's unclear if the case will be dropped. Neymar has scored 10 goals this season across domestic and Champions League matches.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September. UK police traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and will now return to compile a report and update the victims' families. Burmese suspects Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun allegedly confessed but later reportedly withdrew their confessions. They face serious charges, including murder and rape, and could receive the death penalty. The UK raised concerns about the Thai investigation, particularly regarding DNA evidence and suspect treatment. Post-mortems showed Miller died from drowning and head injuries, and Witheridge from head wounds.

Scotland’s women’s football team has won all five of their Euro qualifiers so far and face Iceland—also unbeaten—at Falkirk Stadium in a match that may decide group leaders. Forward Lisa Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, is determined to help the team avoid past disappointments after narrow misses in previous tournaments. With many squad members playing abroad and bringing valuable experience, Evans believes this boosts the national team’s strength. She recently celebrated a league win with Bayern and emphasized the importance of continued focus and fan support as Scotland aims for its first major finals.

Apple is enhancing iCloud security following the theft of celebrity photos, which was linked to third-party software exploiting weaknesses in its system. The company now includes two-step verification for iCloud backup access, requiring a code sent to a trusted device in addition to a password. This optional security measure can prevent unauthorized access using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. While Apple's changes address past vulnerabilities and add features like email alerts for backup downloads, concerns remain about the security and usability of recovery keys. Experts argue that two-factor authentication should be enabled by default rather than optional.

UKIP won the May election, spending £2,956,737 on their campaign—68p per vote. The Conservatives spent the most at £2,980,815 (79p per vote), while Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote). The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) but lost all but one MEP. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372. Total spending by the six top parties was £9,347,087. All except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival and may face his former club soon. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams to manager Kevin Nicholson, is joining subject to international clearance. Nicholson describes Anderson as a strong leader and Keating as young and eager. The Gulls are struggling, sitting four points above relegation with only one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. He was found to have suffered a rare severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite having previously shown symptoms of overheating and post-race ataxia, he had no underlying health issues at the time. The incident has prompted the British Horseracing Authority to seek a better understanding of such rare occurrences. Many Clouds was a successful horse, previously winning the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Several Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs), including Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie, delivered emotional farewell speeches as they step down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond reflected on Scotland's unity and the parliament's growth, while McNeil highlighted the need for improved accountability and learning from Westminster. Marwick was visibly moved by the speeches and praised the contributions of the departing members.

The live-action Beauty and the Beast film, directed by Bill Condon, will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May and release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Other cast members include Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and a new actress as Mrs. Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its charging decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, which killed 96 football fans, at a private meeting with victims' families. Fifteen suspects are linked to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster’s cause, and eight to a separate police conduct probe. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, express hope for accountability after a long struggle, following an inquest ruling last year that the victims were unlawfully killed.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, often containing contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A former inmate described the prison as "notorious" for smuggling, while a local resident said she had seen packages being thrown several times recently. Although the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence of drone use at the prison, it acknowledged the issue and emphasized staff efforts to prevent smuggling. New laws allow up to two years in jail for those who smuggle goods into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright’s car outside a school in Kempston. Wright, 55, admitted hitting her but denied dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. The incident occurred while Mrs. Blackburn was helping pedestrians cross the road. She is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court. The trial is ongoing.

Middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary exams in May. Although disappointed, she prioritizes her degree while remaining optimistic about future athletics opportunities, including targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. At the recent World Athletics Championships, Muir placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, setting a new personal best in the latter. She remains confident in her athletic future, mentioning the potential for competing in multiple future Olympics.

Trevor Deely, 22, went missing in December 2000 after a Christmas party in Dublin. A search has begun in a wooded area in Chapelizod as part of the investigation, which is expected to last several weeks. Gardaí are reviewing the case with enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely speaking to an unidentified man in black near his workplace, who later appears to follow him. Authorities have appealed for this man to come forward.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165 after injury setbacks, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in his first Grand Slam appearance since 2014. He will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, expressed joy at returning to competitive tennis. Also in Andy Murray’s half of the Wimbledon draw, Nick Kyrgios came from behind to defeat Dustin Brown in five sets and will next face Feliciano Lopez, who also won in five sets. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga recorded routine second-round wins.

Tunisia risked expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints about officiating in the 2015 tournament but avoided disqualification after apologizing to Caf. Morocco, initially banned for refusing to host the 2015 event over Ebola concerns, was reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The Tunisian controversy stemmed from a disputed penalty in their quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, prompting a strong but ultimately conciliatory response from their football federation. Both Tunisia and Morocco resolved their issues with Caf and joined the 2017 qualification draw, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive appearance in the finals.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most successful teams with 182 wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is now struggling to achieve even modest results. Their decline began in 2013 with chassis issues despite having a strong engine, and now they face problems with underperforming Honda power units. Historically dominant in the 1980s and late '90s, McLaren's reputation has also suffered from scandals in 2007 and 2009. Despite recent struggles, team boss Ron Dennis and driver Fernando Alonso believe a turnaround is coming, citing progress with the car and hopes for engine improvements. For now, belief in future success is all that remains.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where police later found patrons and evidence of alcohol being served past legal hours. The bar was ordered to close for three months. License holder Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge criticized O'Neill’s record, noted the bar was improperly run, and fined her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season by hitting eight in a game where he scored 45 points, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers. Klay Thompson added 26 points as the Warriors overcame a 13-point deficit. For Portland, LaMarcus Aldridge and Damian Lillard led in scoring. In another game, the Chicago Bulls rallied from a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol contributing 16 points and 15 rebounds. Miami struggled after halftime, missing their first 12 shots and being outscored 57-27.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood, posing as a contest-winning fan before impressing them with his free-kick skills. Initially believed to be an ordinary supporter, van Velzen showcased his talent, stunning the players and earning their admiration. Van Velzen, known for his viral football videos, described the experience of playing with his idols as amazing and satisfying.

A study shows that women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy), particularly if done soon after diagnosis. The procedure was linked to a 62% drop in breast cancer mortality and a 65% reduction in all-cause death, with benefits most pronounced for BRCA1 carriers and those with oestrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. For women who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis, the mortality reduction increased to 73%. BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene mutations carry a lifetime breast cancer risk of up to 70%, and this type of cancer is often aggressive and resistant to treatment. Experts suggest making oophorectomy part of early treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, after lingering on the tracks. The train, No. 80 "Carolinian," was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one person received treatment after falling ill during the delay. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to an acquaintance. The train was delayed for approximately two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellín cartel member, spent 27 years working as an undercover informant for the DEA in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. His work aided in major prosecutions, including those of Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro was never granted citizenship, received no pay, and now faces deportation due to expired legal status and declining health. The DEA refused to assist after he went public with his situation. Toro fears for his life if returned to Colombia and remains in legal limbo, unable to access social security benefits without citizenship or a green card.

The U.S. internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices involving the '.sucks' domain. The company has been accused of exploiting celebrities and brands—such as Kevin Spacey, Taylor Swift, and companies like YouTube and Visa—by charging up to $2,499 annually to secure their names and prevent reputational harm. ICANN had initially approved the domain but backtracked after industry backlash, labeling the business model a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." Regulatory action is being considered.

In 1988, the body of a stillborn baby boy was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. He remained unidentified and was buried by villagers. In 2023, police exhumed the body during a case review and used DNA testing to identify the mother. She had concealed the pregnancy and claimed the baby was stillborn. No foul play was found, and she was arrested but not charged with infanticide. A new headstone naming the baby "Peter" was placed with support from a stillbirth charity. The case, unsolved for 27 years, was closed using modern DNA techniques.

Kristopher Hicks, 27, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi in Bath in 2010, leading to lifelong care needs. The driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed Hicks planned to avoid paying the fare and unlawfully detained him by driving back toward the taxi rank. Hicks jumped from the vehicle at over 20mph, resulting in permanent injuries. The High Court ruled the driver unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and awarded him compensation, reduced by 50% due to his decision to jump. Hicks also received £250 for the unlawful imprisonment. The final compensation amount is pending, with both parties allowed to appeal.

Severe storms triggered tornado sirens in Kansas on Wednesday night, with multiple tornado sightings reported, including one near Goddard that narrowly missed Wichita. Additional tornadoes were seen in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage and flooding. Social media users shared images of storm damage, including hail and ominous clouds. More storms are forecast for Thursday across the Midwest and surrounding regions.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to clash in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, with both fighters eyeing a title shot. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth straight win since losing to Vitor Belfort, plans to pressure Machida by dominating with aggressive tactics and his all-around skills. Despite respecting Machida’s style, Rockhold believes his diverse abilities give him a broader path to victory, especially on the ground. Machida, confident in his own techniques and preparation, believes his strategy can neutralize Rockhold and earn him a title opportunity. Both fighters are coming off recent wins and see this bout as a stepping stone to a championship fight.

A light general aviation aircraft piloted by 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis made a gear-up (belly) landing at Aero Acres Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, when the landing gear was not deployed. The plane skidded along the runway, damaging its propellers, but the pilot managed to re-engage the engines and take off again. Remarkably, he flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The incident, likely caused by human error, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted disappointment with Yaya Toure's performances but pledged to support him until the season's end. Despite underperformance, City will consider offers for Toure in the summer as part of a squad overhaul. The team is struggling, with poor recent results, injuries to key players like Vincent Kompany, and scrutiny on Pellegrini’s leadership. Goalkeeper Joe Hart emphasized player responsibility and expressed continued support for the manager. Separately, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce advised Aaron Cresswell to carefully consider potential transfers to big clubs like City, citing past cases where players saw limited game time.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will not be extradited to Italy after his prison sentence, issued in absentia in 1999 for mafia association (Cosa Nostra), was deemed expired under Italian law. Initially ordered to return to Italy, the 65-year-old’s case was dropped after the court ruled the sentence was too old to enforce. Despite his conviction remaining, the European arrest warrant was withdrawn. Legal experts criticized the time and cost of the failed extradition, partly caused by delays and errors by the UK Crown Prosecution Service.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by A.P. McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy’s final ride in a Grade One race before retirement. He will face six rivals, including Special Tiara, Sprinter Sacre (ridden by Nico de Boinville), and Somersby. McCoy's final day riding schedule will be confirmed on Friday. Notably, he announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory in February at Newbury.

Marcia Trimble was raped and murdered by Jerome Sidney Barrett in 1975, and her body was found 33 days later. Her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, had avoided viewing the crime scene photos at the advice of her late husband but chose to see them decades later, saying she now wants revenge. Barrett, linked to the crime through DNA evidence, was convicted in 2009 of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years. The case had been one of Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murders for over 30 years.

Rory McIlroy, currently ranked world number one, is determined to win the Masters and complete the career Grand Slam, a feat achieved by only five other golfers. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta—where he lost a four-shot lead—the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons that led to future major wins. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy believes the course suits him and hopes not just to win once, but multiple times. Following personal and legal challenges in 2014, he sees the golf course as a sanctuary and is eager to focus on performance amid the pressure at Augusta.

The passage highlights a variety of trending stories from the week, including: quadruple rainbows in New York, exotic dancers at funerals being banned in China, Robert Downey Jr.'s tense interview, the #kyliejennerchallenge lip-plumping trend, a 102-year-old revisiting her past through film, a controversial prom-posal, Ewan McGregor cast in *Beauty and the Beast*, Johnny Depp’s transformation in *Black Mass*, a pregnancy announcement referencing *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air*, and a military dad photobombing his son.

Hundreds of children in England were hospitalized last year with brain damage caused by foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), with 272 confirmed cases, though experts believe the true number is much higher. Research suggests that at least 1 in 100 UK babies, or around 7,500 annually, may suffer from FAS-related issues such as learning difficulties, physical deformities, and organ damage. The condition is permanent and under-diagnosed, with warnings that current alcohol consumption guidelines for pregnant women may be too lenient.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as "boomerang boy," was sentenced to six years in prison after attempting to rob a store in County Durham with an axe. During the robbery, shop owner Sab Dhillon tackled McKerry, while his wife Sam hit the robber with a baseball bat to disarm him. McKerry, who had a long criminal history including over 80 arrests by age 15, was arrested at the scene and later pleaded guilty to attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—have been charged with gang rape following an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian military base in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The incident allegedly occurred after a hockey game on April 10. The accused, who were part of the Royal Navy ice hockey team, must remain in Nova Scotia under strict bail conditions: surrendering passports, residing at the Stadacona naval base, staying employed by the Royal Navy, and not contacting the victim or witnesses. They face charges punishable by up to 14 years in prison, and the investigation is ongoing.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton’s Syndrome, an extremely rare genetic skin disease that makes his skin red, scaly, and prone to infections. Due to his appearance, Valerie has faced public misunderstanding and false accusations of child abuse, including an incident where armed police were called while she applied cream to him in a store. RJ requires constant skin care, including frequent moisturizing and bathing routines. Despite the condition’s challenges, including bullying and social exclusion, Valerie and her husband Reginald remain devoted to managing his care. She discovered the diagnosis through an online support group, after doctors failed to identify his condition at birth.

The controversial “Are You Beach Body Ready?” ads by Protein World featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield sparked widespread backlash for promoting unrealistic and sexist body image standards. Over 50,000 people signed a petition for their removal, many images were defaced, and 216 complaints were submitted to the Advertising Standards Authority. Despite defending the campaign as health-focused, Protein World received bomb threats and criticism from public figures. Transport for London announced the posters’ removal, stating the paid three-week period had ended. The debate ignited significant social media outrage, but Protein World maintains the campaign was successful and will not alter its advertising approach.

Rail companies have faced backlash for fare hikes of up to 87% planned shortly after the general election, contradicting political promises to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron, whose constituency is affected, has urged First Great Western to review the increases, particularly on routes between London and the Cotswolds. Changes affect off-peak return fares, with some rising from £33.30 to £62.40. While some advanced tickets may offer cheaper options, other routes—such as those serviced by London Midlands and Virgin—also see steep increases. Passenger advocacy groups and politicians criticize the hikes amid pledges to control fare growth.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals in Oldham. The incident occurred while he and his new wife Elaine, 54, were writing thank-you cards following their recent wedding. The attackers had initially thrown stones at their home, prompting Mr. Young to open the door, where he was hit directly in the face. Despite emergency surgery, doctors couldn't save his eyesight. Police have launched an investigation, citing no known motive, and suspect the attack may have been an act of random vandalism. The couple now plans to move due to safety concerns.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from leg injuries sustained in a 2014 road accident that also claimed his father's life. Following ankle surgery, he made his comeback during the team's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. Derbyshire praised his determination and form, expressing confidence in his continued performance.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford has been declared cancer-free after battling neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children annually in the UK. Diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck, Harley underwent intensive treatment including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. To cope, he decorated his radiotherapy mask like a Ninja Turtle, which helped him feel braver and won admiration from hospital staff and public attention. He received gifts from Nickelodeon and was recognized with Cancer Research UK’s Little Star Award. Harley's story has inspired support for cancer research campaigns for children.

Jack Grealish is being urged by Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood to focus on his club career rather than his international future. After impressing in Villa’s FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, Grealish is being courted by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes that the decision is up to Grealish but insists his priority should be securing his place in the Villa first team. Grealish’s father agrees that his son should concentrate on club football for now, with a decision on his international allegiance expected at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the high and varied landing fees at airports for private jets, a concern for wealthy travelers. Private jet travel is a booming industry, worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with millions of flights annually. The most expensive airports for landing fees are primarily in Japan, with Haneda Airport charging the highest at £4,559 ($6,850). Other costly airports include Narita and Kansai (Japan), Toronto (Canada), Darwin (Australia), Bristol (UK), Dublin (Ireland), and Salzburg (Austria). These fees reflect the popularity and exclusivity of these travel hubs among the rich and famous.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. In a viral video viewed over seven million times, Daisy eats slowly while Cooper devours the cone in one bite. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she feeds Daisy first. Some viewers criticized her for giving ice cream to dogs, but she defends it, citing the dogs’ good health. Another video shows the dogs enjoying a Starbucks "pup-uccino," with Cooper again quickly consuming the treat.

Gary Locke has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager after a successful interim tenure, signing a three-year contract. Previously the assistant to Allan Johnston, he took over in February and has lost only one of seven games since.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims that Seminole County Elementary School threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because the essential oils he wears to help him stay calm and focused were deemed a distraction due to their smell. The oils, made by DoTerra and including scents like lavender and chamomile, had reportedly been used by Logan throughout the year until a teacher’s aide complained. Kemp received a letter from the school board referring to the oils as a "problem" but argued for their continued use. Despite the initial threat, the school district later stated Logan would not be suspended, calling it a health issue.

A fire destroyed the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, burning through 90 condos and causing the building to collapse. The fire began around 3 p.m. on Wednesday, producing smoke visible from three miles away. Despite efforts from 12 fire crews, the blaze was too intense to enter the building, melting paint on nearby structures. The cause is under investigation, with reports suggesting it may have started near a parked car. The complex, used as holiday homes between May and November, left residents and staff devastated, including the building manager who lost everything.

Queen Elizabeth II, approaching her 89th birthday, continues to ride her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor despite a knee injury and not wearing a helmet, favoring a silk scarf instead. Known for her lifelong love of horses, she began riding at age four and has maintained an active role in breeding horses, including fell and highland ponies. The fell pony, an ancient British breed valued for its strength and temperament, has a rich history dating back to the Iron Age and remains a popular riding horse today. The Queen breeds them at her Hampton Court stud.

A noise dispute between Brisbane neighbors ended in tragedy when 55-year-old Leon Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. Yeaman was reportedly making loud noise late at night, disrupting Pama's sleep before a confrontation occurred. Pama claims he hit Yeaman blindly while being pushed. Yeaman died at the scene. Pama, a married father of three with no violent history, has been charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail. The case will return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, was caught on hidden camera trying to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old former student and lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit and provided explicit instructions for the boy to suffer before she would "finish him." The hitman was actually an undercover police officer, and Simonova was arrested after handing over money. She now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief at her arrest and hopes she is imprisoned long-term.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, revealed he prays daily and has strong faith in God, though he never prays about football. He separates his professional and personal life, never discussing football with his wife. Mourinho and his family have been involved in humanitarian work with the World Food Programme. Despite his on-field persona, he believes he is a good person in his private life. Professionally, he acknowledges making mistakes in a competitive and emotional environment. Chelsea currently leads the league and faces QPR next. Mourinho was recently fined for suggesting bias against his team.

Bob Barker, former longtime host of "The Price Is Right," returned to the show on April 1 for the first time in eight years. At age 91, he briefly hosted a pricing game before turning the show back over to current host Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker performed smoothly.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested early Friday morning in Washington, D.C., for allegedly attempting to break into a house. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and property destruction. The arrest occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE, and Baldwin has been placed on leave with his security clearance revoked. He was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch of the agency. His court arraignment was set for Friday afternoon. This incident follows another misconduct case involving a high-ranking supervisor, as the agency faces multiple ongoing investigations and scrutiny.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, risked his life to photograph a hungry lion from just 10 feet away in Lahore’s safari park. He left his car to lie on the ground and capture a few close-up shots, but the lion noticed him after hearing the camera shutter. Saeed narrowly escaped by scrambling back into his car as the lion charged. Reflecting on the experience, he later admitted he likely wouldn’t attempt such a risky act again.

New York City police are seeking help identifying an unnamed woman, aged 25 to 45, who was found unconscious and later died on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn. She had no ID but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg showing the name "Monique" within a heart and rose design. The NYPD released images of the tattoo in hopes of finding her identity, and the cause of death is still pending a medical examiner’s report. Information can be reported to NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009, unable to afford traditional property. Over a year and a half, they constructed the home themselves using wood and steel, incorporating features like a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and water from a nearby spring. Now living nearly self-sufficiently on a lot in Nelson, New Zealand, the project cost them about $25,000, and they plan to build another in the future.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored about 30 points higher in early literacy tests than those who used iPads individually or not at all. The study, involving 352 students over an academic year, suggests the improved outcomes are due to collaborative learning around the technology. Blackwell recommends schools rethink how tablets are used to maximize their effectiveness in early education.

A two-legged piglet from Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters due to being born without hind legs. Nicknamed "Super Pig," the piglet amazes viewers by maintaining balance and socializing with its four-legged siblings. A video showing its efforts has captured widespread attention online. The piglet belongs to a farmer named Ms. Duan, who discovered its condition at birth. Similar admiration has been shown in China for other two-legged animals, such as a rabbit in Guangxi Province that walks on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured when Francesco Dracone lost control of his car while exiting the pit on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches and was released from the infield care center. Wet track conditions from earlier rain caused traction issues for many drivers. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cícera Alves de Sena, by slamming her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. The attack, captured on CCTV in Rio de Janeiro, occurred just four days after their marriage. Severiano confessed to the crime, citing jealousy over men looking at her. After the killing, he attempted to flee in a stolen car but was apprehended following a crash. Police recovered multiple weapons and a bulletproof vest from his vehicle, and he now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of *I Quit Sugar*, opened up about her battle with mental illness, revealing she once felt life was not worth living due to anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and isolation. In a candid interview, she shared how these struggles made her feel alone and without direction. Wilson emphasized the strong link between anxiety and depression, noting anxiety is becoming increasingly common among Australian women. She now accepts her anxiety and believes acknowledging its connection to depression is key to addressing rising mental health issues.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault in 2014 after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar upon finding her using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charges, deeming Curtin's actions justified under Oregon law, which allows force against intruders who refuse to leave. Curtin gave birth in January and has since moved in with her parents. Her defense claimed the ex-girlfriend had harassed her for years and contributed to the boyfriend’s ongoing drug issues. Avoiding trial spared Curtin a potential six-year prison sentence.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed reacting with disgust after being tricked into eating broccoli among treats, which she promptly spit out. Despite her dislike for vegetables, she enjoys spending time with her human family and relaxing at home.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic site. This occurred because the web address for the discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards, scrapped in 2011, was taken over by a porn site after its domain registration lapsed. HSBC removed the link upon discovery, clarified it had no association with the external site, and assured the public that its website remained secure.

Thirteen-year-old Marcus from Maryland called 911 after a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom with his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, he stayed calm during an 11-minute call, gave firefighters directions, and comforted his sister. Firefighters rescued them through a window, and both children were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other three family members escaped and were taken to another hospital.

Amazing images have captured blue fluorescent algae lighting up Jervis Bay on Australia's south coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the neon glow, caused by millions of light-emitting plankton, as a “beautiful supernatural scene.” The phenomenon, also seen in Sydney’s Manly Beach in 2014, is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms naturally in spring and autumn. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers explained the algae emits light as a defense mechanism and is not harmful.

New genetic tests like EndoPredict can assess the aggressiveness of breast cancer and help determine a patient's risk of recurrence, potentially sparing many women from undergoing chemotherapy. These tests analyze cancer cells after surgery and can identify patients with a low risk—sometimes as low as 5%—for whom chemotherapy offers little additional benefit. While these tests are currently costly and mostly available privately, experts advocate for their use in the NHS due to potential cost savings. Patients like Becca Cornford have used EndoPredict to make informed decisions, avoiding chemotherapy and its harsh side effects when it’s unlikely to improve outcomes.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen ships had emergency pregnancy evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule suggests conceptions occurred before deployment or during leave. Commander Sarah West was flown home amid misconduct claims. Since 1990, women have served on Royal Navy ships, with 9% of personnel female by 2014. Between 2006 and 2013, 99 pregnant British servicewomen were evacuated from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq, as military rules prohibit pregnant women in war zones. Most pregnancies began in the UK, though some may have occurred on duty.

A drone containing traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence, prompting terrorism concerns. The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, was discovered the same day a court approved restarting two nuclear reactors. Though the radioactive material was not immediately harmful, authorities are investigating and considering new drone regulations. The incident highlights security vulnerabilities, especially ahead of major events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Abe was not present at the residence at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's to work with him daily on his motorbike to prevent her from getting lost. After his father's death and with no one else to care for her, he ensures her safety by tying them together and riding slowly. His employer has provided her with a room, and he regularly checks on her. Lu says he is repaying the care his mother gave him as a child.

A major study by the University of Washington found that heavy drinking in the U.S. increased by 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by rising rates among women. Binge drinking among women rose significantly—over seven times the rate among men nationwide. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% binge drinkers. Although overall alcohol use remained stable, cultural shifts, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies contributed to the rise. Alcohol-related deaths reached about 88,600 in 2010, and excessive drinking cost over $220 billion annually. The study used data from 3.7 million adults and was the first to analyze county-level drinking patterns.

UN officials, including the World Health Organization, warn that doctors are too readily performing caesarean sections, risking the health of women and babies. They stress the procedure should be used only when medically necessary due to potential complications like infections or even death. In England, over 25% of births are by caesarean—more than double the rate in the early 1990s—partly due to maternal anxiety about natural birth. WHO recommends a lower rate of 10–15%, criticizing current NHS guidelines that allow caesareans without medical need. The procedure also imposes higher costs on the NHS and may divert resources from other patients.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a Martha’s Vineyard home, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner’s belongings in a yard sale. Filkins was discovered by homeowner Mark Conklin sitting in his property, valued at $800,000, and fled when confronted. She was later arrested after trying to re-enter the home. Filkins faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who obtained items from the yard sale to return them and may assist victims in seeking restitution. She is due in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a party in Melbourne, and it was handed in to Albury Police Station. The phone was unlocked, so officers posted humorous selfies and puns on her Facebook page to locate her. These posts quickly gained attention online. When Bella came to retrieve the phone, officers recognized her from Facebook, and she didn’t need to provide her name. Impressed by the humorous approach, Bella thanked the police and has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed after being caught in a violent fight between two adult male hippos in iSimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf was flung into the air and dragged through the water as its mother looked on helplessly. Despite attempts to protect it from other hippos, the mother could not save her baby, which died from its injuries hours later. The incident was witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, one of Britain’s most expensive areas, is on sale for £575,000 due to having only three years left on its lease. The flat, which requires significant renovation, offers 1,990 sq/ft of space and could be worth over £6 million if the lease is extended. Extending the lease could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. A second larger maisonette nearby is also for sale for £595,000. Both properties are attracting strong interest due to their rare short-lease status and potential high value if modernised and lease terms are improved.

A computer outage on Friday affected registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, prompting some stores to give away free drinks and baked goods. The glitch, caused by a failed daily system refresh, disrupted credit card transactions and led to early store closures in some areas. Excited customers shared their free drinks on social media, while others faced store closures. The issue was resolved by late Friday night, and stores reopened Saturday as normal. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are reportedly training and radicalising individuals in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to DC Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Extremists engage in ordinary community activities while hiding their true intentions. Historical incidents link Islamic extremist activity in Wales to as early as 1998, with known terrorists previously training or operating in the region. Michael Adebowale, involved in a major UK terrorist attack, studied at an institute in West Wales linked to Iraqi clerics. Authorities stress the importance of community intelligence in combating terrorism.

A rare Omura's whale, previously feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia following Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting in the state and only the second in Australia. The juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant due to the species’ rarity and limited scientific knowledge, as it was first described in 2003 and typically inhabits tropical areas like Indonesia and the Philippines. The whale’s remains will be studied further, with the skeleton potentially displayed in museums.

The passage critiques the idea that hormones make women unfit for presidential leadership, focusing on comments by Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman who claims Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to female hormones. The article counters this by highlighting historical male leaders whose decisions may have been influenced by testosterone, research showing women take fewer unnecessary risks, and the broader issue of persistent gender bias. It argues that the true barrier to female leadership isn't biology but societal prejudice, and emphasizes the wide-ranging benefits — economic, familial, and societal — of achieving gender equality in leadership roles.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, aged 89, is auctioning off his extensive collection of over 200 antiques—including paintings, weapons, furniture, books, and a hand-painted 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt—through Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, as he downsizes his home. A passionate military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, Hardy studied under Tolkien and C.S. Lewis and has published books on the subject. Known for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small*, as Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in *Harry Potter*, he is retiring from stage acting but plans to continue in television.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is wanted by police as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. He went missing after failing to appear for a scheduled visit with his son, prompting concern. Authorities suspect foul play and possess the murder weapon, though details of the killing remain undisclosed. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, past legal issues, and was undergoing a stressful divorce. Neighbors believe the divorce and related tensions may have contributed to the incident. He was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication.

Eugene, USA, has been awarded the 2021 IAAF World Championships, marking the first time the event will be held in the USA. The IAAF Council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity. Although Eugene had lost the bid for the 2019 event to Doha, a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city's capability. The decision involved collaboration among public authorities, the private sector, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. A similar precedent occurred in 2007 when Osaka hosted the championships without a formal bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Kent, was sentenced to 16 years for manslaughter after helping lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death as part of a plan to steal his winnings. Granger targeted Hassan after meeting him at a London casino, using her looks to gain his trust. She left his flat door unlocked, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to enter, tie up, and fatally beat Hassan while robbing him. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, robbery, and conspiracy to falsely imprison, while Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum of 36 years. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge.

Cesc Fàbregas began the season strongly for Chelsea, appearing on track to break the Premier League assist record with 15 by mid-January. However, his form has declined significantly in the second half of the season—a trend noted since his time at Barcelona. In Spain’s 2-0 loss to Holland, his poor performance continued, raising concerns about his durability. Despite this, Chelsea remains well-positioned to win the league, and manager José Mourinho hopes Fàbregas can recapture his early-season form to help secure the title.

West Ham are close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a two-week trial at their academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, is considered a top Caribbean prospect and also has interest from Belgian clubs. Additionally, West Ham announced season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, aiming to offer the cheapest prices in the Premier League for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, just three months after it occurred, despite substantial evidence including video footage, a suspect photo, and car registration numbers. Lane was attacked by masked hunt saboteurs armed with iron bars; he suffered serious injuries including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The decision to shelve the case due to "insufficient evidence" has drawn criticism from Lane, witnesses, and hunt supporters. The Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban face coverings used by saboteurs to help identify and prosecute offenders. Wiltshire Police stated the case could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, an American and prominent al Qaeda propagandist also known as Azzam the American, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, according to the White House. Not specifically targeted, Gadahn was known for his English-language videos threatening Western targets and encouraging extremist attacks. Born in California in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al Qaeda in Pakistan in 1998. He rose in prominence after 9/11, becoming the group's chief English-language spokesman, and was indicted for treason by a U.S. federal grand jury in 2006. His final video was released in 2014.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a viral sensation in China for his extraordinary basketball skills, which he began developing at the age of two and a half. A video showcasing him dribbling two basketballs and scoring multiple hoops has impressed many, drawing widespread praise and sparking admiration across the country. His talent has led to comparisons with professional players and generated enthusiastic reactions from netizens.

Tom O'Carroll, a convicted former member of the paedophile information exchange (PIE), attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on February 25 to support state regulation of the media. Hacked Off campaigns for media reform following phone-hacking scandals and backs creating a statutory press regulator. O'Carroll’s support is seen as an embarrassment to the group. PIE, which he actively supported, controversially sought to legalize child sex and lower the age of consent in the 1970s and 80s.

On Thursday, Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained to host a unique catwalk show for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, displacing regular lap swimmers. The event featured Ten Pieces, a unisex fashion label led by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcasing a monochrome capsule collection of ten items designed to be worn 20 ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall with an ocean backdrop, while guests enjoyed warm weather, refreshments, and minimalist, androgynous designs. The public also gathered to watch the show from nearby vantage points.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a day with his wife and daughter at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, where they interacted with animals like giraffes, sea lions, and a rare white tiger. Earlier that week, Khan confirmed he would fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite pressure to face British rival Kell Brook and links to other potential opponents.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was murdered by three Israelis in July, was initially included on Israel's national memorial for fallen soldiers and terror victims. His family and the organization Almagor objected to his inclusion, arguing that his death was a rogue act and not terrorism. Following complaints, including from his father who opposed having his son listed among Israeli soldiers, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial and its website.

A young boy is filmed by California-based YouTube user Lionel Hutz persistently trying to use his cat's belly as a pillow. Despite the cat repeatedly moving away, the boy follows and lies on him again, until the cat eventually retreats indoors. A later video shows the two reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, who lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after admitting to past marijuana sales. Kushner testified that officers stole cash and drugs during a 2007 arrest. His criminal history, including expunged charges, a 2011 arrest, and a 2008 DUI, came as a surprise to school officials. The trial centers around six former officers charged with crimes such as racketeering and extortion, while defense attorneys claim the case relies on untrustworthy witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire, which has since been controlled. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast was caused by an oil leak at a storage facility, with no toxic spill reported. Over 600 firefighters responded, and most injuries were due to broken glass. The plant had a previous explosion in 2013. Originally planned for Xiamen, the plant was relocated after public protests over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa and Ireland U21 player, insists he will continue wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to a lifelong superstition, despite repeated warnings from referees. He recently made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction at the opportunity and hope for more starts, while acknowledging the challenging nature of the match.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive, despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston and other sources. Though Bobby Brown recently stated she was awake and watching him, family statements clarify that while her condition has improved and she is in rehabilitation, her long-term quality of life is uncertain. She has a tracheostomy and shows no neurological responsiveness.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki in three sets, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's straight-sets win over Julia Goerges. Despite serving issues, Pavlyuchenkova overcame Lisicki, whose 63 unforced errors were critical. Russia now needs one more win from Sunday’s remaining three matches to secure a spot in the final, aiming for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents in New South Wales, still recovering from last week's severe weather, are being warned of another potential storm later this week, possibly bringing floods and further damage. Meteorologists predict an east coast low could deliver heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday, particularly affecting northern coastal areas and the Hunter region. The State Emergency Service (SES), overwhelmed with over 24,000 assistance requests from the previous storm, is concerned new weather could hinder ongoing cleanup efforts. More than 4,000 jobs remain incomplete, and over 1,000 SES personnel, including interstate aid, are working to prepare and assist communities.

Model Nina Moric, known for appearing in Ricky Martin's video "La Vida Loca," denied Italian media reports claiming she attempted suicide. She explained on Instagram that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after collapsing and suffering injuries from a fall. Moric expressed shock at the suicide claims and stated she is now recovering at home. Her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso initially supported the media's claims, but Moric clarified he was not present during the incident. The model has previously faced similar reports in 2009. She was formerly married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov poll shows that many Brits hope for a baby girl named Diana, after William’s late mother. Diana is the most popular name choice, followed by Alice and Charlotte. If it’s a boy, James and Alexander are favored. A quarter of poll respondents want a girl, while only three percent prefer a boy. Public support on social media mirrors this sentiment, with many expressing strong emotional hopes for the name Diana. Additionally, 68% support William’s six-week paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied involvement, and no group has claimed responsibility. The protesters were en route to a rally against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite seven successful years with the team, including winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, he could not agree on a new deal. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that contract negotiations—centered around a three-year extension contingent on Alves playing in 60% of matches—are over.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors, has urged his former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. He believes their playing styles suit South American football and that Boca fans would enthusiastically welcome them at La Bombonera. Osvaldo praised both players' abilities and popularity, suggesting they would be perfect fits for the team.

Teenage amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson became an internet sensation after a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse at Wincanton, which left him with only a cut on his nose. Despite the incident, he resumed stable duties and riding the next day at Paul Nicholls's yard. Ferguson reflected on the fall with humor, noting the support from fellow jockeys and joking about a future in gymnastics.

James Haskell, the London Wasps rugby captain, celebrated the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron* by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram. Haskell, who began his career with Wasps in 2002, left in 2009 to play in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to the club in 2012. Since then, he has made over 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 England caps.

The wide-leg trouser is emerging as a major Spring/Summer 2015 (SS15) trend, offering an alternative to the long-dominant skinny jean. This style comes in various forms including denim, cropped, printed, and striped, and has been featured on major runways like Gucci, Céline, and Stella McCartney. Fashion experts Louise and Emma recommend styling it with high heels and simple tops to maintain proportion and elongate the legs. Denim versions are the most accessible and flattering way to try the trend. The look is both stylish and practical, suitable even in cooler weather.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of "American Sniper" after over 200 students petitioned against it, citing concerns over its portrayal of the Iraq War and its impact on perceptions of the Middle East. The cancellation faced backlash and a counter-petition. Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper later announced the decision was a mistake and reinstated the screening, citing the university's commitment to free expression. An alternative film, "Paddington," will also be shown. The reversal was praised by Michigan football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly tried to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. The men, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and are due in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Detectives seized video evidence during the investigation.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at New York clubs in the 1930s and 1940s, saw herself dancing on film for the first time after volunteers compiled early music videos called "soundies" for her. Previously, she had never seen the motion pictures she appeared in and had lost all her memorabilia. She was delighted by the experience.

The tradition of washing one's own car in Britain is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting they never do it. A survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV found only 12% of men who do wash their car do so regularly. Reasons for the decline include busier Sundays, the convenience of hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes. Only 5% of parents ask their children to wash cars for pocket money. More people wash their cars during holidays, though often just to get out of the house. Washing frequency varies by city and car brand, with Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs most often cleaned by their owners.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard’s influence since joining Liverpool in 2008, calling him one of the best players in the world and a symbol of the club. Though acknowledging Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, who is set to leave for LA Galaxy after possibly ending his Anfield career in the FA Cup Final on his birthday, Skrtel believes the team has potential replacements. He also credited Gerrard for helping him settle at the club. Both players may return for the semi-final against Aston Villa after serving bans.

At age 75, golf legend Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, thrilling the crowd. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus aced the 130-yard fourth hole, his first hole-in-one at Augusta. Despite this highlight, Camilo Villegas made two aces on the same day, with a total of five aces tying a 2002 record, though Kevin Streelman won the contest. Nicklaus, who won his first green jacket in 1963 and sixth in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri as storms moved through the region Wednesday night. A tornado was spotted northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, while others were reported near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. In Missouri, a possible tornado hit Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. Severe weather, including unusual clouds and hail the size of baseballs, was reported in nearby towns. More storms are expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy in Tulsa County, Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he meant to use a Taser. Despite the charges, a judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which drew criticism from Harris's family. Bates said the shooting was accidental and has apologized; officials including Sheriff Stanley Glanz also apologized. The Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and benefited from preferential treatment due to donations and personal ties. There are also allegations of forged training records, which the sheriff's office denies. Bates’s lawyers released documents to support his qualifications. A preliminary hearing is set for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas. In the lead-up, he revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla chest tattoo. McGregor claims he is more motivated to win the title than Aldo is to defend it. Their rivalry intensified during a promotional tour in Dublin, where McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt in front of 5,000 fans.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking advocates and academics after skolling a beer at an Australian Rules football event, an act seen as glorifying binge drinking and reinforcing harmful masculine stereotypes. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert argued the act promoted a culture of excessive drinking and warned against public figures showcasing this behavior. Although Abbott was cheered by players during the event, critics, including Robert, expressed concern over media and political responses that appeared to normalize or praise such actions. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his overall healthy lifestyle, while opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked the incident. The controversy reflects broader concerns about changing attitudes toward binge drinking in Australia.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary cases in Scott County, primarily among intravenous drug users using the painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day emergency needle exchange program on March 26, which has distributed over 5,000 clean syringes. Health officials expect more HIV cases as testing increases and are urging an extension of the program. However, Pence opposes needle exchanges on anti-drug grounds, and the program's future, along with proposed legislation to expand such programs to other high-risk counties, remains uncertain. The outbreak highlights broader public health concerns, including funding limitations and ideological opposition to harm-reduction strategies.

An Arsenal-obsessed fan created a detailed test for his girlfriend, Saskia, to assess her knowledge of his favorite football club. She scored an impressive 87% (43.5 out of 50), earning an ‘A’ and praise from her boyfriend, who humorously declared he wouldn’t dump her. The exam mimicked a real school test, complete with multiple-choice questions, written responses, and teacher-style feedback. Saskia shared the experience on Twitter, where responses ranged from admiration for her effort to criticism of her boyfriend’s intensity. Fans praised her knowledge, calling her “proper girlfriend material,” though some felt the test went too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years, providing critical information that helped prosecute major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro began working with the DEA after fleeing Colombia for his safety, and although promised U.S. citizenship for his service, he never received it. Now retired due to declining health and living in the U.S. illegally, he faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. Despite his vital contributions, the DEA has refused to assist with his citizenship, leaving Toro in legal limbo and unable to collect social security benefits.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village, set herself on fire and is now in critical condition with 70% burns in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital. Her family allegedly told her to remain silent about the incident. The accused men have been arrested. The case adds to growing outrage in India over sexual violence, particularly following the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, which led to nationwide protests and calls for stronger protections for women. Other recent vigilante incidents highlight rising tensions over sexual assault cases in the country.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford on Sunday, aiming for victory over rivals Manchester City to help United secure a top-three league finish and avoid Champions League qualifiers. However, key players Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw are ruled out, as van Gaal does not consider them match fit despite their claims. He emphasized the importance of controlling aggression, referencing the previous 1-0 loss to City, and expressed confidence and ambition while praising the support of United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest followed the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal and highlighted ticket prices starting at £64. Organized by fan groups, the demonstration aimed to raise awareness about the financial burden on supporters, with banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing." Fans called the prices "extortionate" and warned that continued cost increases could alienate future generations. Further protests were planned after the match.

Newborn baby Star Reader was diagnosed with the life-threatening liver condition biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, doctors confirmed she would need a liver transplant. Since neither parent was a suitable donor, Star’s mother’s twin sister, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver, saving the baby's life. Star underwent the transplant in November, spent six weeks in the hospital, and has since made a good recovery. She will need ongoing medication and testing, but now has the chance to live a normal life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi’s football challenge, competing in teams of two. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, which involved hitting targets on cars and playing football over an Audi used as a tennis net, taking a strong lead. Remy and Willian won the final round, shooting into convertible Audis from long range. During this round, Willian accidentally broke a car’s wing mirror, prompting a shocked reaction from Remy, though no penalty was expected.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault after causing a fatal highway crash in December 2013. He drove his truck across a median at over 100 mph, killing Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, Jason Timmons. Though he initially told investigators he was trying to kill himself, Dellinger later denied being suicidal. His defense attributed his behavior to health problems and medication effects. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. The sentencing is ongoing.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison after being convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. Prosecutors argued she caused his suffering and death to gain attention through social media and hospital visits, despite portraying herself as a devoted single mother. Her lawyer maintained her innocence and plans to appeal. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed outrage at the sentence on Facebook, wishing Spears harm in prison. The judge described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty" and noted Spears showed no emotion at sentencing.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month late, designed to protect against two new strains—H3N2 and B/Phuket—which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US due to a mismatch with the previous vaccine. The updated vaccine also protects against H1N1. High-risk groups, including the very young, elderly, and most Indigenous Australians, can access free government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, recommend widespread vaccination to better protect vulnerable populations, noting the same vaccine will be used in both Australia and the next northern winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic, which called the site lacking in historical character, and they are concerned about potential budget cuts that could affect its management. The critique comes during the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s assassination. Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that oversees the tomb, further raising concerns about its future. Despite reduced staff and hours due to past funding cuts, over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations have left the tomb in excellent condition. Designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, the tomb has undergone major reconstructions and remains an important historic site, though opinions vary on its presentation.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, some of which are met with skepticism. Key trends making a comeback include chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo T-shirts. JNCO jeans, with extremely wide legs, are returning despite past criticism. Other revived styles include the bucket hat, camouflage print, exaggerated fashion like double denim, Ugg boots, denim shorts (Daisy Dukes), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear, and harem trousers. These styles are now sported by modern celebrities such as Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, Selena Gomez, and Nicki Minaj.

The passage summarizes trending stories from the week, including rare quadruple rainbows in New York, a Chinese crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for funerals, Robert Downey Jr.’s tense interview moment, the viral #kyliejennerchallenge, and a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past on film. Other notable mentions include a controversial prom invitation, Ewan McGregor’s casting in *Beauty and the Beast*, Johnny Depp’s dramatic transformation in *Black Mass*, creative pregnancy announcements, and a military dad’s original photobomb.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory with a win over Sabine Lisicki, advancing to the Miami Open semi-finals, where she will face Simona Halep. The tournament featured celebratory cakes for career milestones, following Andy Murray’s 500th win. Williams overcame a tough three-set match and avenged a prior Wimbledon loss to Lisicki. Her sister Venus’s loss ended hopes of a sibling showdown.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani human rights activist, was shot and killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion on the sensitive topic of disappearances in Baluchistan. Founder of the café and community space T2F, she was known for promoting free speech, human rights, technology, and women's issues. Her outspoken activism made her a national symbol of tolerance and courage in a country where such expression is dangerous. Despite previous death threats, she continued to create space for open dialogue. Her death sparked nationwide grief and highlighted the risks faced by advocates of progressive values in Pakistan.

Around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), primarily Hindus who fled Pakistan during the 1947 partition, have lived in Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir without full citizenship rights for nearly 70 years. Denied the ability to own property, vote in state elections, or access state jobs and education, three generations have remained trapped in poverty. The WPRs’ exclusion stems from a law granting rights only to those with ancestral ties to the former kingdom of Kashmir and fears of upsetting the Muslim-majority state's demographic balance. However, with the Hindu nationalist BJP joining the state’s ruling coalition, there is renewed hope among refugees for long-denied rights and improved living conditions.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer. Though Chelsea intends to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem, Muto prefers a club where he can play regularly and develop. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut, praised his intelligence, speed, and potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto and noted that commercial interests, like the club's £200 million deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, can influence transfer policy, though performance remains a key factor.

The passage argues that England should follow Australia’s lead in allowing national team selection of overseas-based players. It praises Australia for dropping the policy that excluded such players, highlighting Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell’s strong performances for Toulon. The author criticizes England coach Stuart Lancaster’s refusal to consider talent like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon, whose games have improved abroad. It asserts that winning the World Cup requires picking the very best players, regardless of club location, and that restricting selection based on domestic ties is outdated and detrimental.

Open Garden’s FireChat app enables messaging without internet or mobile signal by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or Android’s Bluetooth-based equivalent. Phones act as nodes, passing messages locally within about 200 feet (61 meters). To extend this range, the company developed Greenstone—an egg-shaped device that boosts signal and stores messages until another FireChat user comes within its 20-foot (6 meters) range. Greenstone can facilitate resilient communication in places like festivals or protests and is currently in development, working only with FireChat while Open Garden seeks manufacturing partners.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses her work and a TED Talk to challenge negative perceptions around the word "fat," embracing it as a neutral, body-positive descriptor. She highlights how societal attitudes label "fat" as undesirable, especially among women and youth, contributing to discrimination and insecurity. Through performing, which she began in 2012, she empowers herself and others by promoting body diversity and confidence. Her TED Talk, posted in 2014 and later uploaded to YouTube, received mostly positive feedback, inspiring many viewers to reevaluate body image.
