Bustle expresses hope that exposure to diverse body types fosters greater acceptance.

Theo Walcott has spent much of the season on Arsenal's bench, being named a substitute in 17 of 33 league games. He recently appeared in a Lanvin fashion photoshoot with several teammates and model Olga Sherer. Walcott hopes to start in an upcoming game against Hull, having only made a brief appearance in the recent draw with Chelsea. Arsenal players will wear Lanvin attire for the upcoming FA Cup final.

A large collection of over 400 movie props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on Propstore.com. Valued at approximately $746,100, the items come from more than 50 productions spanning Baker’s 30-year career, including *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, and *Harry and the Hendersons*. Notable pieces include the alien Edgar Bug ($40,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), and props from *Moonwalker* and *Thriller*. The auction offers fans and collectors a rare chance to own parts of Hollywood history.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell from Wales died in a tragic skiing accident in Flaine, France, after becoming separated from his family and falling 164 feet in dense woodland while heading toward the resort he saw through trees. A skilled skier and adventurous child, Carwyn was described by his grieving family as loving, outgoing, and full of life. His body was found by police following his footprints in the snow. The community, school, and family are mourning his loss, remembering him as a vibrant child with a love for the mountains and farming.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to pressure to be thin. She became obsessed with weight loss, surviving on as little as one piece of fruit per day, hiding food, and lying about meals. Her health deteriorated, and she collapsed from starvation, requiring hospitalization and heart monitoring. After treatment and support from eating disorder services, Laura began recovery. She now speaks out about societal pressures on girls to be “size zero” and has regained confidence, progressing to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a pageant promoting positive body image.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, designed by New Balance after a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. Key players, including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, modeled the kit during the launch event. Despite rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract and expressing interest in Arsenal, Sterling received support from fans who urged him to stay. Both Sterling and Sturridge emphasized the importance of fan support and shared hopes of FA Cup success, with a semi-final against Aston Villa ahead. The shirt features tributes to Hillsborough victims and debuts a new collar style.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have released the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, the first in a series from the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES). The map, covering about 0.4% of the sky (150 times the area of the full moon), uses data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Blanco telescope in Chile. It reveals clumps of invisible dark matter, which make up 85% of all matter and can only be detected via gravitational lensing. Scientists measure the distortion of light from galaxies to infer the presence of dark matter. Eventually, the project aims to create a 3D map covering 12.5% of the sky. This work helps explain galaxy formation and will advance understanding of dark energy, believed to drive the universe’s accelerated expansion. So far, the findings align with theories that galaxies form in regions with concentrated dark matter.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay. Manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay during Holland’s 2014 World Cup run, is eager to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Tottenham previously failed with a £15 million bid, and other top clubs like PSG are also interested. Depay began his career at amateur side VV Moordrecht and joined PSV at age 12. Known for his speed, dribbling, and powerful shooting, he is seen as a future star, with some comparing his potential to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. He made a significant impact at the 2014 World Cup, scoring twice and earning a nomination for best young player.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 advantage in the Youth Cup final first leg against Manchester City in Manchester, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke adding a late third. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly equalized for City. Chelsea’s young team, featuring standout performances from Abraham, Solanke, Clarke-Salter, and Colkett, dominated much of the game. City’s youngsters, including Brandon Barker, Adarabioyo, and Nemane, showed promise but struggled to contain Chelsea’s attack. The win gives Chelsea a strong position heading into the second leg in West London.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, stated that he believes people are born with a sexual preference but does not support same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. He maintains that marriage should be defined as between a man and a woman and that states, not courts, should decide on its definition. Despite his stance, he said he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cared about. Rubio compared this acceptance to his views on divorce, which he opposes as a Catholic but would not let affect his love for others. He recently announced his presidential run and has already secured over $51 million in donor commitments.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia, left their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended global cycling journey. Traveling on a minimal budget of under €3 per day each, they rely on camping, hosting sites, and the kindness of strangers for accommodation, and spend most of their budget on food. Over nearly a year, they’ve covered around 7,000 miles through 16 countries from London to Armenia. They plan to continue into Asia, eventually aiming to cycle across the Americas, documenting their low-cost, pedal-powered adventure along the way.

A Texas couple is suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act after racist slurs allegedly appeared on photo booth prints from their 2012 wedding. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, claims Evans refused to apologize and told them to "sue" him. The bride's sister delayed informing the couple to avoid ruining the wedding day. Evans denies the allegations, citing lack of evidence and mental anguish. The couple is seeking an apology, not money. Mediation is scheduled, and trial is set for July if no settlement is reached.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovery after a concussion, unsure of when he’ll return to play for Harlequins. He withdrew from a recent match due to lingering symptoms after the France game and emphasizes the importance of recognizing concussion signs, crediting online education modules for increasing his awareness. Brown, previously knocked out during the Six Nations against Italy, is determined not to rush back and risk long-term health, learning from cases like George North and Johnny Sexton. He is advocating for greater concussion awareness as part of Land Rover’s ‘We Deal In Real’ campaign.

Research cited by Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University shows a decline in sexual activity among Britons since the internet's rise, with the average heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, down from five in 1990. He attributes this trend partly to increased smartphone and internet use, which blur boundaries between work and personal life, reduce private time, and shift priorities away from intimacy.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized in China and sold for up to £1.2 million, have rapidly declined in popularity and are now being slaughtered for meat. This shift is attributed to factors including China’s anti-corruption crackdown, bans on owning large dogs in major cities, urbanization, overbreeding, and decreased breed quality. Once status symbols and herding animals, many mastiffs now face neglect, abuse, or are stolen and sold to slaughterhouses, with some breeders offloading unsellable or poorly bred dogs.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area revealed that all had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half reporting their first incident before age 18. Harassment ranged from verbal abuse to sexual assault, often going unreported and leading women to alter their daily routines out of fear. The findings prompted calls for a public campaign to combat sexist behavior on transit. Officials emphasized the need to educate women, aggressors, and witnesses, and stressed that such behavior severely restricts women's freedom and access to public space.

Direct Line launched a competition called #everydayfix, asking people to identify common daily emergencies and commissioning design group Makerversity to create prototype solutions. After surveying 2,000 people, top issues included sleep problems, lost keys, and phone battery failure. Three finalists were selected: 'Snooze' (an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to aid sleep), 'Forget Me Lock' (a key attachment showing door lock status), and 'Nipper' (a tiny mobile charger powered by household batteries). The public could vote on Twitter, with the most popular design progressing to a Kickstarter campaign. Other prototypes not shortlisted included a parking alert device, a message-forwarding app, and a navigation helmet.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice after awarding over £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co-directs with Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics, including MP Keith Vaz, have called the funding decision a conflict of interest and labeled it inappropriate. The Ministry of Justice is examining whether conflict of interest rules were breached. Despite the criticism, Baird insists all protocols were followed. Sim, who previously faced bullying allegations, has announced her retirement. The charity was created after a decline in use of its predecessor, Victim Support.

In Philadelphia, three individuals were imprisoned and two others face sentencing for torturing a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, over accusations he harmed a cat. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, along with Sandra Ng, 19, and Carl Halin, 18, beat, tied up, and tattooed offensive images and words on Valecce, filming the abuse over 42 hours. Campbell and Halin were sentenced to 20 years, Ng to 23 months. Valecce escaped and suffered serious injuries. Two more people—David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt—await sentencing or trial. All involved pleaded guilty.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who previously coached him during the 2014 World Cup—keen to make him a key summer signing. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Formerly pursued by Tottenham and currently attracting interest from top European clubs including Paris Saint-Germain, Depay has been compared to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Known for his pace, dribbling, and powerful right-foot, Depay began his career at VV Moordrecht and rose through the ranks at PSV, debuting in 2011 and signing a professional contract in 2012. Internationally, he scored key goals for the Netherlands during the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 advantage over Manchester City in the Youth Cup final first leg with a strong performance in Manchester. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke added a late third. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly leveled for City. Chelsea’s players, including Abraham, Solanke, and defenders like Jake Clarke-Salter, delivered standout performances. City's young squad, featuring the likes of Brandon Barker and Kean Bryan, showed promise but struggled against Chelsea’s dominance.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that people are born with a sexual preference but believes same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right. He argued that marriage laws should be decided by state legislatures, not the courts, and supports the traditional definition of marriage as between a man and a woman. Despite his stance, Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a loved one out of respect. He also compared his views to his Catholic belief that, while he opposes divorce, he would still love divorced individuals. Rubio recently announced his presidential bid and has reportedly secured over $47 million in donor commitments for the campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, quit their restaurant jobs to pursue an open-ended global cycling journey starting from London. With no fixed agenda, they have traveled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries over 356 days, living on less than €3 per day. They keep costs low by camping, using free hosting platforms, and eating basic, often donated or foraged food. Their journey has taken them through much of Europe into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue through Asia and the Americas over the coming years.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion sustained during the Six Nations. After experiencing prolonged symptoms following matches against Italy and France, he pulled out of games, including Harlequins' clash with Saracens and England’s match against Ireland. Brown emphasized the importance of concussion awareness, crediting World Rugby’s online modules for helping him recognize symptoms and avoid long-term risks. He advocates honesty about symptoms and urges fellow players to prioritize health. His comments were made during the launch of Land Rover's "We Deal in Real" Rugby World Cup 2028 campaign.

Research highlighted in Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book "Sex by Numbers" shows that the frequency of sex among Britons has declined since the rise of the internet, with typical heterosexual couples now having sex three times a month, down from five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter and other experts suggest that increased smartphone and internet use, along with blurred boundaries between work and private life, may be contributing to this decline by reducing couples' available time and focus for intimacy.

Tibetan mastiffs, once status symbols in China commanding prices up to £1.2 million, have seen a sharp decline in popularity due to an anti-corruption crackdown and city bans on large dogs. Once gifted to officials by businessmen, these dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, with many suffering cruelty during transport. Overbreeding and crossbreeding for profit weakened the breed’s quality, leading to an oversupply of unsellable dogs. Urbanization has further reduced their appeal, as they are not well-suited to city life. Rescues reveal the harsh conditions and mass culling now facing the breed.

A competition called #everydayfix, run by Leeds-based Direct Line, invited design groups to create products addressing common daily emergencies. Based on a survey of 2,000 people, top issues included trouble sleeping, losing keys, and dead phone batteries. Three finalist prototypes were created: 'Snooze'—an alarm clock that connects to a phone and silences notifications for better sleep; 'Forget Me Lock'—a key device that indicates if a door is locked or not; and 'Nipper'—a tiny phone charger powered by household batteries. The public can vote via Twitter, and the winning product will be developed through a Kickstarter campaign.
